												Beyond the technical presentation, Sacred 3 feels like little more than a cheap mobile game. All you do is grind your way through samey levels, punching samey enemies with samey attacks, and you never feel rewarded for any of it. The cinematics are well produced, the graphics are okay and the soundscape is generally decent, but when the gameplay is so incredibly void of interesting mechanics, and never rewards you for all the monotonous grinding, it’s a hard sell at €50. Even if you ignore the fact that it’s supposed to be a sequel to a series of games that play completely differently, the game doesn’t become any more acceptable as its own thing either. Far better games can be found at far lower prices. The other Sacred games, for starters.2/5Full review:http://pixeljudge.com/en/reviews/sacred-3/

												Ok guys i try not to write bad reviews but this game is just missing everything sacred has been over the years. The quest, freedom and diversity we know and love is gone and replaced by an arcade game with bad cut scenes and disgraceful gameplay.This Sacred game starts out with terrible jokes and tries to be funny in the cutscenes. From there you go into a arcade score values hack and slash with no loot, no real level up system and very very little freedom. In the first hour of the game you are fighting the same enemies and bosses while auto attacking with fiddly controls and annoying voice over for combos. The only damage numbers are for critical hits and interrupts. Not to mention the options menu that was made for atari. Sacred 3 would be a nothing but an indie game that you pick up for under $10 on a steam sale, if it didnt have 2 very successful games in the series to start off with. To play a game with no real goals and a boring story line that has been used before i suggest spending your well earned cash on something more enjoyable and that would last longer, like pizza or a haircut.  I personally do not recommend this game at all. If you still want to pick it up steam sales when its around $15 bucks would be your best bet.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												The most disappointing game I have played in a long time. A series of rather high quality in-depth action rpg's made into a simplistic, almost primitive arcade-style game I would expect as a gaming hall or browser title, not a full-price wanna-be blockbuster. An all-use ingame currency instead of diverse loot, near to no armor or weapon variation and customization. As well as hardly any attack or skill variation: light attack, heavy attack (shield breaker), and 2 skill slots with 5 alternatives to use in each, that's it, no diverse combat, just button mashing. Linear and quite limited maps instead of a living, breathing, npc-settled open world. One mission / level after the other with point recap in between, just like stages in a 90's arcade side-scrolling game.I'm usually the last one to totally dismiss a game but I can only advise anybody to never touch this one, especially if you expected this to be a diablo / sacred style action rpg. Console port is in fact a very small excuse for (imho) destroying a (rather) popular and quite high quality game series like this.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Sacred 3 is the third game in the Sacred series. The game play and design is strikingly different to the two previous games.  The game was released on PC, PS3 and Xbox 360 in August 2015. Unlike the first game, Sacred 3 is a hack and slash brawler. Every single one of the levels is linear, there are no quests to complete; just a simple get to the end of the stage without dying. There are plenty of classes to choose from at the start of the game with all of the classic RPG ones available such as warrior, rogues, mages and marksmen.  The game play is extremely watered down too; with each class only being able to have two active abilities and a weapon set. The lack of any loot drops throughout the game really means this brawler has no rewards for even completing stages.  In between the story missions, Sacred 3 also offers side missions which to be frank, are absolutely pointless. They can be completed in less than five minutes and yet again, offer no real reward for completing them. Every single mission in this game is 100% linear, only one route to the end, and one way to kill any of the bosses. There are a few scenes which sees you running through corridors of falling rocks and lava, but nothing that really keeps you on the edge of your seat. All of the enemies in the game are just more of an annoyance than anything else. None of them present any kind of threat to you and you will not die. I didn’t die once whilst completing my play through. To be honest, I am not sure how to rate the graphics in Sacred 3, at times the game looks really well fleshed out with some of the scenery in the levels looking very good. But then at some points, it just looks awful. The textures and background views are bland and very low res, almost to the point where it takes you out of the immersion as you are just astounded at how bad it looks.  Now the audio is whole new ball game – this has got to be the most cringe worthy voice acting I have ever heard. The unfunny one-liners, the sexual innuendo, and some quite blatant sexism that comes out of the characters mouth’s is mind boggling. I did have to eventually mute the game just because I couldn’t concentrate on playing the game because of how awfully bad the voice acting is. The narration through the whole story is just as bad too; the random comments that add no other benefit to the game and only drag the seriousness of the Sacred series down to a kindergarten standard. Sacred 3 is not a hard game at all. Like I said, I completed the whole game without dying. You are able to change the difficulty of the levels on the fly, meaning you have no real downside to starting the game in hard mode and then lowering the difficulty if needed; but there won’t be any need. Once you get to grips with the controls you’ll be able to dodge, outrun and out manoeuvre anything the enemies throw at you. I was expecting a sort of open world game in Sacred 3, to be able to wander off the beaten track into buildings and caves to find my own adventure; but sadly that is not the case here. The are quite blatant caves and buildings that look like they are really interesting to explore, but the game has put up invisible walls all over the place prevent you from exploring. The game can also be completed in a short amount of time considering the rest of the series were 20+ hours. I finished this game in just under seven hours. Yes I could play another character, but why? I would only be playing the exact same linear missions all over again and have exactly the same experience just with one or two different spells to cast. The game has up to 4 player co-op, but I honestly don’t see any reason why you would want to make the whole experience even easier than it already is.One part where Sacred 3 does have some pluses, is that I didn’t have any technical issues whilst playing. The game has a wide choice of resolution options, whilst the graphical options are limited, the game is well optimized to run on anything (probably why it is on console). The game can also be played with a game pad, but I had the best experience when using keyboard and mouse. In conclusion, I can’t recommend Sacred 3. Fans of the series will be bitterly disappointed with this game, and even new people to the series will find nothing original in here. There are so many more much better made hack and slash games out there, Sacred 3 should only be played when you can get it for less than £3,99 – not a penny more.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												This is Sacred in name only, be warned.Sacred 1 and 2 were wonderful open world games, with lots of loot, and a decent combat skill selection. They both had decent stories and character progression. My advice for franchise fans, is to go replay sacred 1 and 2, skip this. If you pre-ordered like I did... I am so sorry. This game doesn't even pretend to be the same genre.This is an isometric brawler with very limited combat. There are no selection of combos, no character customizaton, no hot swapping skills, and no loot! You pick from a limited selection of skills (you get 2 in mission, from a limited pool), and a selection of weapons that are nigh identical, but must be unlocked through the story. Combat is repetitive, oh so repetitive. Controls are somewhat awkward on the PC. This seems to be geared more towards a console platform in that regard.The voice acting is decent, and for sacred fans, the cheesy lines are still there, but that may be all that remains. There is little to no character development, and the story itself seems to be a tired reincarnation of "evil being attempts to destroy world for some reason". Graphics are not bad... not great, but they certainly could be worse. If you want a simple brawler, this is alright, but not worth the $50 price tag (there are similar, much cheaper titles available). Give this one a pass. R.I.P. Sacred

												If your after anything like the original games save your money as this is nothing at all like Sacred 1/2 but more like Sacred Citadel 3D. This game is an insult to the original fans of Ascarons Sacred franchise. It appears to be nothing more than a cash cow for Deep Silver.You have four races to initially choose from (the fifth race is DLC). No open world. A linear mission quest line. Your equipment consists of two items; an armoured suit (which can be upgraded but NOT replaced) and a weapon (which you can upgrade and replace). No loot drops other than gold, health orbs, energy orbs and weapon spirits. Skills, armours and weapons can only be upgraded/unlocked/bought with gold after meeting level requirements. You cannot directly upgrade your characters attributes. Levelling a character increases your health and may increase combat arts energy. Completing the relics quests (stars missions on map) will unlock new items for you to buy in store and increasing capacity is done in the circle missions. You can only equip three skills at a time; a light combat art, a heavy combat art and a battle prayer (the battle prayer is co-op only). Upgrading and equiping can only be done outside of the mission quest. More bonus gold can be earned by using combos and playing co-op (this will heavily impact single player as your gold will increase much more slowly). There's no real strategy other than bashing buttons to kill your enemies with combos which becomes boring after a while due to its repetitive nature.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												As many others wrote before, this is not a game that can be compared to "Sacred" or "Sacred 2". This is true but this is in itself not necessarily a bad thing - there are many hack'n'slash games over there. The problem is that even 'Diablo' (the first one, that is) makes much better work that "Sacred 3".Almost every single typical h'n's element is simplified or removed. There is no traditional loot items, no equipment to be found, no crafting, no skill trees or any other similar character development mechanics, no freedom of movement. New weapons, armour and powers (you can use only two at the time) need to be unlocked and bought for gold (not unlike in many arcade games). So, if you're a fan of Diablo-like games, you may pass this title. If it reminds me anything, it may be a tad similar to "Lord of the Rings" for PS2 (and is definitely closer to LotR than to "Torchlight" or "Titan Quest". Also, it was made with drop-in multiplayer in mind, so the single-player experience suffers substantially.Sure, the game graphically pleasant to the eye, but not really imaginative and the cutscenes seem to be sloppy (I understand that you making good looking static pictures is not a simple task, but we're speaking an AAA game here, not some amateur production). Music is completely forgettable. Run of the mill heroic tunes with nothing interesting added for good measure. English voiceovers are average verging on bad, the humour is infantile at best. German looks a bit better but again, nothing to write home about. It is painfully obvious that authors wanted to be a bit tongue-in-cheek take on fantasy, but they did not have any idea how to make a comedic piece. So, really, it is rather disappointing.Also, there are some flaws that got me really disappointed. Dodging, extremely important in arena battles with bosses works haphazardly when you're using mouse and keyboard (but judging from the control scheme I belive this is not an issue with gamepad, did not try it though). Saving progress is also unintuitive and it is quite easy to lose progression in a given mission. Difficulty is rather unbalanced - I found that easy, even boring sequences are lead to very hard boss battles. It gets better the farther you go, but sometimes the contrast is jarring what is a tell-tale of poor testing.So, for the final verdict - it is not a _bad_ game and forming a party with friend might be actually fun as the simplistic, multiplayer hack'n'slash games go if you don't mind very poor attempt at narrative. But even then, I don't think it is worth half the initial price. And even then, I strongly recommend to play it on console or on PC with a gamepad. And I definitely do not recommend it to any single-player h'n's fans out there.

It seems a mish mash of the same old "bad guy" out to destroy the world.  The 'cut scenes" are filled with corny lines that I assume are supposed to amuse young children.  This game is still fun, but as long as you can let go of what the Sacred games used to be.  I think Sacred game loyalists need to be warned of this before buying.  Look up game play video and reviews before buying.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												TLDR : Sacred 3 doesn't support any of the typical mechanics of the hack'n slash genre. The experience is closer to a very generic bland and mindless beat'em all. Disappointing, 3/10In spite of all the rather poor "preview" articles, I persisted in thinking Sacred 3 couldn't be *that* bad and decided to purchase the game (pre-order, mind you...). After all, a hack'n slash IS a hack'n slash, right ? Well... not quite :/The game does present itself as an "arcade hack'n slash", but it is actually only a brainless beat'em all. Fantasy action games can take a wide range of shapes and forms, but let's be clear... What do people enjoy in h&s games ? Ignoring all the details, in the most abstract form it fits in 4 major points :- Finding items, to improve their strength ; an endless gear treadmill to become more and more powerful- Optimising their character, by leveling up, equipping armor pieces, favouring offense/defense stats choices, etc.- Defining their experience through gameplay choices (skill tree or similar, inventory, stats, etc. or any combination of the above)- Combat ! Well, that's the core of the action, so... It should be "fun", aka "challenging & rewarding"Sacred 3 does not support any of these gameplay elements. The game has as much depth as Golden Axe. This is like Dungeon Hunter 4 on PC, without the (few) fun bits.Enter a small area ; defeat a bunch of enemies (read "spam LMB", pro-tip use skills 1-2 to kill things faster) ; collect meaningless orbs ; move onto next area ; rinse & repeat. After a few times, BOSS ! Yeaah, exciti... ah, no. My bad. You can spam LMB, but can you dodge AND spam ? Oh, you can ? I guess you're too good for this game, well done, you cleared a mission ! How interesti...zzzZZZZZ...Seriously, how can a game decently call itself a h&s without having a loot system !I am not very far into the game myself (and probably never will be...) but I understand the base campaign can be completed in less than 10 hours on the first playthrough. The game does seem a bit overpriced for that kind of duration.Bottomline, avoid this piece of s...oftware !

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Ahh to recommend this game or not..... I really want to.... I really wanted to like this game.... but still can't recommend it and here's why.Firstly I'd like to point out that I know this isn't truly a sequel to Sacred 2 and that my opinion on the game isn't influenced by this, I wanted to give an unbiased opinion on this game as a stand alone.So as you may be aware it's a linear action RPG.... and by linear every single map is virtually a straight line with no chance of going off and exploring the areas. The map zones are nice and the graphics are good enough; but you always feel really limited over what you can do. Aside from the fighting you get to run along a corridor and avoid falling debris..... on every major map zone - not always debris, maybe lightning, but basically the same thing and it gets repetitive quickly. Same goes for turning a wheel 6 times to move a bridge, open a door etc - happens too often and it becomes doing the same thing again and again.The controls feel weird at first but after a few zones you get used to them although even at the end you'll miss attacks or dodge in the wrong direction after you've lost the cursor on screen in amongst the action.The different characters are varied enough with some options to change and upgrade attacks and weapons which is done by coins collected during missions. The lack of loot in game felt odd but wasn't as bad as I thought (and I love looting in games usually) so don't let this put you off.As for the dialogue..... well..... they try and be funny.... main word being try. Sometimes they get it right and it can make you laugh, but a lot of the time it'll make you groan at how silly it is.Oh and you get a spirit which is meant to help you out and talks as you fight........ by the end I'd been called babycakes at least 100 times - and that was annoying the first time!To give you an idea on how long the game it, I've completed the main quest without skipping a zone in just under 9 hours - there is an option to play online with others but I'd never seen more than 4 people online at once.So like I said I wanted to like this game, I am a big RPG fan especially action-RPGs and didn't want the fact it was not Sacred 2 to change that, but on it's own it's just not a good enough game. Fans of the genre should wait for a sale - I picked it up for £3 so am happy with that with what I got - it's not worth the £15 it's currently priced it.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												This is Sacred no more!As a first-hour-fan of the Sacred series it was a punch in my face when i heard that Ascaron had to close its doors after they developed Sacred 2. Nevertheless i looked forward to Sacred 3, happy about the fact that the franchise will live on. However i am deeply disappointed by what Sacred 3 has become. Everything that made the original games fun and enjoyable has been ripped off in a way, that i have to call it rude.Basically there's nothing left in Sacred 3 that we know of the former games except the Seraphim class and the name of the realm, Ancaria:1: No open world2: No in depth skill system3: No character customization4: Background / Lore1The "world" in Sacred 3 is mission based. Every mission takes place in a linear level with recurring gameplay elements:- Fight- Dodge- BossOk, maybe we have to fight, dodge, fight and then boss, but that's basically everything there is. The level's details are in fact beautiful i have to admit.2I remember reading, printing and studying countless class guides for Sacred 2 for hours, everywhere and anytime i could (BfG Sera, anyone?). All this has become nonrelevant in Sacred 3. You're limited to a skill system with a maximum of two choices at certain character levels. Ok, that was somewhat similar in Sacred 2, however, since you have no gear to choose from, except 3 weapons bound to your class, the skill system feels shallow at best. Your armor gets upgraded automatically at certain levels and has a more cosmetical feel than anything else. Also, there are no weapon sockets anymore, instead you unlock weapon spirits whom provide certain bonuses. Those weapon spirits, unfortunately, feel like commenting on your actions in a manner, that i'd love to play the game in an ancient, long forgotten language, i simply can't understand...3Hairstyle? Haircolor? It wasn't much in Sacred 2, but at least it was something. Combined with your hardly gathered armor set you still felt like caring for that character you played. In Sacred 3, you can't even name your figure. Everything's predefined and done for you already. Level 6? Ok, my armor got upgraded visually, automatically, done. No loot. Just gold to unlock your next skills, limited by character level and in numbers.4To this day, i listen to the audiobooks released with and around Sacred 2. I clearly remember helping Hansi Kürsch and his band Blind Guardian, retrieving their stolen instruments, so that they can do their ingame "live"-performance. I remember the conflict between elves and humans and their very own agenda within Ancaria, aswell as helping the spirit of xmas on that awesome dedicated island. In Sacred 3, all that seems to be gone. As told in the intro, all races send their best fighters to stand against that evil force, witch is noting but some totally unknown elf guy, talking slang language and somehow manages to insult you mentally speaking.ConclusionThis is Sacred no more. Ironically, the original developers are working on a new ARPG title they formerly named Unsacred. Due to copyright issues, they had to rename it to Unbended. For their own good, i say, because Sacred 3 is the true Unsacred.If you feel like forgetting about this game's title, you may end up playing a simple, somewhat entertaining hack'n'slay adventure. If you're new to that genre, this game feels like it's made for that let's-see-how-i-perform-on-those-controller-buttons experience. If you're looking for a worthy successor of the Sacred series, wait for, and support Unbended.Pros:- Graphically beautiful- Fluently playable, even on lower end rigs- MusicCons:- Castrated skill system- No open world- No loot system- No exploration- Flat story- Flat characters- Miserable, bothersome humor- Repetitive gameplay elements

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												As a previous fan of both Ascaron Entertainment's first and second Sacred game, I have to say, this game makes me very sad to experience. I was well aware of the community's warnings and disapproval, but I still got it for the sake of clarity and some itch to keep supporting a previously good developer. Even though it isn't even Ascaron Entertainment that is behind it, I still felt they wouldn't let a game reputation like Sacred slip so easily into wrong hands. (Which... It seems they might actually have..)First and foremost, the story... The first game was brilliant where magic was just magic, where you had to gather elements to defeat a loose Sakkara demon. As fantasy-RPG as it gets.The second game then tried to explain how everything magical was actually run by T-energy, which had started pouring into the world and corrupt it. For the sake of the story, I won't spoil more than that, but it had enough going to keep you going to see what was behind it all.But now with the third game, I don't see any of the T-energy or any enticing lore that keeps you wanting to progress through the story. On top of that, they made it entirely linear, even less open-worlded than Diablo. Gameplay...First and second game was a lovely free-roaming RPG with vast maps and plenty of quests to do along the main one. It was also hack-n-slash and focused on classic gear gathering and skill-progressing. And the combo system in the first game was brilliant, to say the least.Sacred 3 has lost all of this, except the hack-n-slash. No excitement for finding legendary gear and enhance it, no stunning combos which they otherwise boasted about a whole lot, compared to previous games AND went to feel like a side-scroller instead of open-worlded.Pros and Cons about the game...To try not comparing it with the previous games, since it's obviously not; looking at it as the ARPG, hack-n-slash it tries to be, I have to admit it's still fun and challenging and accomplishes what it tries to do. I can imagine it works perfectly fine on console and I find myself compelled to continue playing just to see how powerful I am capable of becoming, but I can already imagine that it turns into a boring grind when you start up new characters after first run through. Controls feels weird when using keyboard/mouse though, so I'd recommend a controller.  So, pro is that they managed to make a decent isometric brawler, but lacks a lot compared to other brawlers.  The cons is that they went WAAAY off their usual way, making one question if they just made it to try expanding into the console and DLC world for the sake of money.Finally, my recommendation...If you are a fan of the previous Sacred games, don't buy this. You'll be severely disappointed and likely come to hate yourself for buying it.If you like side-scrolling, hack-n-slash, brawlers with beautiful graphics and fairly challenging combat (If you play on the hardest difficulty) and don't mind that the price is fairly high due to the title's previous reputation. I would still not recommend it, compared to other brawlers or hack-n-slash. Bastion, Transistor and Diablo does a far better job.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Forward------------------------------------------------------------------"Let's play the name game!" the developers said."You guys have been working on a shell of a game, might as well release it finally." said the lead developer."Ya let's call it Sacred 3!" they all said together in a bro-fist fashion, with teeth grinning and head banging, they shout from the mountain tops "SACRED 3!"Sadly the story ends there, on a sad note.  This ladies and gentlemen is not "Sacred 3" (well it is but not in the vein of...you know what, you know what I mean), it's not even "Sacred 2.8 uncut finalcut master faith 360 degrees drop edition".  It is not even worthy of holding a candle to its name, but does that mean it isn't good?For starters Sacred was known for its killer diablo like ARPG mechanics.  It was a loot all ask questions later type of game and we (the fans, myself included) loved it.  Sacred 2 followed the same formula except updated it in a more modern way, lots of faults but still the same Sacred type of play we love.  Now we come to Sacred 3, this abomination of a game set in the "Sacred" universe.  Let's go over a few things, as to why I don't recommend it.WHY in spaghetti monster's (insert your own diety here) name did they have to call it Sacred 3!?!?-------------------------------------------------------------------This question baffles me, they could have named it anything else, ANYTHING and it would have been absolutely fine, but no it wasn't enough, they had to drag the name through the mud.  If it was called "Sacred: Mini Adventure", "Sacred: Not Serious Edition", "Sacred: Battle of the Bads", I mean absolutely anything this would not be a question.  Everyone would see it as an off-shot and not a sequel, just a fun extra.  Instead they have the balls to call this piece of trash SACRED 3, it is not an ARPG, it was turned into an Action Battle Arena and a very basic and limited one at that.  So enough about the name, I think I shared my thoughts on that quite enough.Combat-------------------------------------------------------------------Extremely basic press key/button to slash, press key/button to do a special, press key/button to dodge/block.  That can be good or bad I suposse.  On one hand it is easy enough for a basic gamer to pick up and tackle without any confusion on the other it just leaves combat to a lacking unimpressive grindfest.  The responsiveness of the controls is fine, they are tight at least and you can interupt your skills to dodge/block which is a highlight, "the knight in shining armor" one would say.  So the combat gets a sideways thumb from me, not bad/not good.Voice Acting/Story-------------------------------------------------------------------Excuse my french here but HOLY ♥♥♥♥ is it ever bad.  Not only is the story completely off the rails down right stupid, everything must be a JOKE!  It's like the writers sat down and were like; "Man this game is horrible, let's just make the dumbest thing we can think of and constantly make fun of it throughout the entire game".  I can not think of any other way this was made except for the extreme reason to punish the developers/publisher to even unearthing this thing.  You will constantly roll your eyes and soon just skip the story cutscenes (art with text/voice...).  Nothing and I mean nothing is taken serious about this game, the main villians are portrayed as idiots.  Like a dumb laughable cartoon villian except you won't be laughing, you will be crying at how bad it is.  Your companions are even worse!  They never shut the hell up, they just keep gabbing as you try to fight your way through a horde of murdering orcs!  When you think it couldn't get any worse, it gets worse.  Absolute thumbs down, you will not care about the story ("story" right) or the characters.Areas/Zones/Set Pieces--------------------------------------------------------------------This is very repeatitive and reused, tons of set pieces are the same and you will see them through the game, ruins, camps, arenas, fire, jungle.  Same stuff, throughout the grind.  There are some story zones that shake things up a bit but they are all linear paths, if it braches off it is just to grab a chest and then come back to fork X and go the other way.  I'll give this a sideways thumbs, again not great but there was some effort...I guess.Level Restrictions/Skills---------------------------------------------------------------------You will hit these hard mid game and even worse late game.  So the base of the whole system is you get xp from killing enemies and completing the mission on the map you are on.  This will then give you some bonus and let you buy skills in the menu.  The skills however are not very different and the whole system is a joke.  Some level ups will grant you companions or lvl up the companion.  You can only go into areas that are your level or lower, so you will get level blocked at some point, what that means is even if you are doing the extra side quest areas you will need to redo a story mode or arena map multiple times just to level up and move on.  Trust me this made me want to quit more times than I can count but I kept treading on.  By the end of the game you aren't even half way leveled up, they have the balls to say, "well play the game again!".  No sir! no sir I will not.  This gets a huge thumbs down from me, level blocking is a horrible system to make a player waste more time in their game doing the same crap they already been through, no one likes that, no one has fun.  No Fun Allowed!Online Co-op/Drop In-Out----------------------------------------------------------------------So if you are lucky to even find anyone online (I found one guy once...) you can drop-in their game or they can drop in yours.  This is neither fun, nor does it help, nor does it hurt.  They are just there...  It's like a ghost on your screen, killing stuff while you kill stuff as you have been killing stuff, with no gain.  There is no reason to play this game co-op unless you just want to play with your siblings or friend.  It is a system that works, but not desired.  Sideways thumb.Closing Arguments----------------------------------------------------------------------It's an action game take it for what it is worth.  Is it worth playing, that is up in the air.  From the fun I had with it (extremely short time, rest felt like I was doing it just to finish it) I would say it isn't worth even bothering loading it up.  It's not a Sacred game, I made that point very clear.  So take it for what you want.Final Verdict----------------------------------------------------------------------Combat - Sideways Thumb, okVoice Acting - Thumb so very far down I'm pointing straight at hell itselfAreas/Set Pieces - Sideways Thumb, mehLevel Restrictions/Skills - Thumb down, shame on you developers!Online Co-op - Sideway thumb, alrighty thenRating: 2 Stinky Fish and an octopus (You might not mind the octopus, but the stinky fish will deter you otherwise)Please friends! Move along, nothing to see here.  For those that dare to dream, I'll just say I warned you.

Posted: December 13, 2016
												All the (extremely) negative reviews on here boil down to one complaint: Sacred 3 is nothing like its predecessors. It isn't an ARPG. Instead, it is -- as the description already makes clear -- an isometric, arcade-like hack-and-slash game, or to put it in even simpler terms: a topdown brawler, similar to Gauntlet. In fact, I'd say it's better than Gauntlet: quicker, more fair, and more colourful. The "humour" I could have done without, but it's lame enough to be easily ignored. The bottom line is simply this: if you're invested in the earlier Sacred games, you're better off giving this a miss. If, on the other hand, you don't care at all about the earlier Sacred games, and approach this as the arcade brawler that it is, you're likely to enjoy it quite a bit. Me, I came to this game after having played Sacred Citadel and Castle Crashers, and it fits into that niche quite nicely. This is, by the way, a great game to also play casually with a friend.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												This game is slightly better than its reviews suggest. Oh, it's bad - a poorly conceived and designed mess, but with lowered expectations it's a passable timewaster. The kind where you just switch off your brains and mow down enemy hordes. On the one hand, the fundamentals are kind of solid (if uninspired), the graphics are decent and there's quite a bit of variety. On the other hand, you've got nearly everything else. I'll get into its writing in a second, but I do need to mention that the design is awful; some of the character progression is actually ok for this sort of thing, but others just... pop up, randomly, with no explanation or logic. Some of the combat systems are ridiculous, too - there's a "fatality" type move that you can pull on bosses where you just... immobilize them, and inflict tiny bits of damage. Took me a while to figure out that it's meant for co-op play; as a solo player, it's ridiculous that it's still available as an option without getting buffed up. You expend your healing Items throughout the missions without any way to recover them, which means that you may reach the end boss- where you'll likely need them the most - without them unless you refrain from using them. None of the design problems are a huge issue except when the difficulty spikes up, in which case you'll spend a fair amout of time cursing at the screen (the last underworld mission, especially its boss, is one of the worst "♥♥♥♥ you's" I've ever seen designers aim at their paying customers). But that's an isolated case, difficulty has been fine elsewhere. I got this mainly to play co-op with my wife, who loves this sort of thing ever since Baldur's Gate - Dark Alliance; the problem is that after watching me play a couple of levels, she wants nothing to do with it. The writing is just that ♥♥♥♥ing, offensively bad. Offensive in its stupidity, not in any sort of premeditated, comedic way. It's disposable fantasy twaddle without the slightest hint of personality except for a smug sense that it's the funniest thing ever, even though it doesn't seem to understand the basics of a joke. You get bombarded with its noxious brand of humor throughout the missions, and it's almost painful. Let me put it this way, it throws in a Larry the cable guy quote at one point. It's even less funny without any sort of context. TLDR version - It's a brain dead, ok-ish action-RPG with a really obnoxious personality and some pretty stupid design decisions. I'm kind of enjoying it... kind of, and even that in a sort of MST3K way. However - even if it sounds like your kind of thing, wait until it's at about 10% of its current price (shouldn't be long!). It won't be worth it even then, but it's not like there are a lot of couch co-op, controller-enabled games for the PC.

number of helpful: 25 of 28 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Oh dear where do I start with this. It's gonna be a long one!As a long term fan of the Sacred series, cutting my teeth for the first time in the world of Ancaria back in Sacred 1 in 2004, and then on to greater glory in Sacred 2 in 2009... the news that developer Ascaron Entertainment had gone under was a massive blow. Hope was on the horizon however when Deep Silver announced they had purchased the rights and that Keen Games would be working on Sacred 3! Oh yes! More Sacred! More Ancaria! MORE LOOT!Now in 2014 we finally get to play Sacred 3, so much time has past! Teaser videos and screenshots, discussions across forums about "what we hope for", rumours... finally we can play! Sacred 3 is here and... what the hell is this? This isn't Sacred!Sacred 1 and Sacred 2 were "open world" action RPG's. Classic isometric camera angles, an almost free-form camera in Sacred 2. Tonnes of loot! I remember spending many hours farming for dual light-sabers on my Seraphim... Seemingly endless expanses to explore, lots of depth to crafting your own combat arts just how you like them. Stat points to build character... character customisation; want a character with bright green hair in Sacred 2? No problem!Sacred 3 is none of this. Well apart from sharing the name and "isometric camera angle" - and I say "angle" 'cos it's a fixed camera.Sacred 3 chooses more to go down the route of an "action game with some RPG elements". By that I mean, you will gain XP and level up - but you will have no "points to spend in stats".You will still fight using "combat arts" - but its less about building them bit by bit as we did in past Sacred games and more a case of spending gold to purchase upgrades for them.There is no more open world. The game starts you off with a lengthy tutorial. Once you complete that, you are returned to the menu where you can pick through locations on a map to take on individual challenges. They range from the main "story" maps - largish maps with lots of mobs and a boss at the end... stamina test maps where you have to hold off against 5 waves of mobs... and simple "clear the map of enemies" missions. After each mission is complete you will need to stand in a circle to be teleported back to the menu to choose your next adventure.There is no apparant "droppable loot". Every so often you will kill a mob or a boss and you will be alerted that you have found an item, a sword, etc. However you will not be able to take a look at it or equip it until you have exited out of the current "challenge" and are back at the lobby/menu. Here again you can choose to upgrade your weapon by spending gold to add extra features to it. Same goes for armour, skills, and combat arts as I mentioned above.There are no character customisation options. You can no longer tweak how your character looks before you start to play. You can't change their name either. "Claire - The Seraphim Paladin" for instance is one of the available playable characters/classes. You are stuck with the way they look. However, as I mentioned previously you can upgrade armour and weapons - and as you do so you will notice slight changes to your chosen characters visuals.The game itself is beautiful, it plays well. The voice acting is awful. Sacred is known for tacky humour, Sacred 2's seraphim often quipping sarcastic remarks, but Sacred 3 is just over-the-top, stupid "in your face" - trying to be funny and failing completely - a miserable attempt at humour.If you come into this game expecting a great RPG experience, either as a RPG fan or as a fan of the Sacred series, you will be disappointed. However if you approach this game without that mindset, and consider it a game of it's own accord then it can stand up - just about!This really should have been a new IP, or a spin off from Sacred. This I will warn you now, is NOT a Sacred game - at least not in the true sense of what we have come to know. Overall however, it still falls short. To me it feels like a very hollow RPG. While playing I did mention to my friend that it felt very much like playing a Free To Play MMO, very watered down and basic. You will be button mashing in this game - a LOT and you will feel as if it is more a "brawler/beat-em-up" than RPG.Playing CoOp was fun however and does make the game more enjoyable. So if you want to play with a group of friends, it may be worth while looking into. However at the RRP of £39.99, I really couldn't "recommend" it. If it drops to around £10-£15 - at a stretch £20, it would be worth checking out. But even that would be pushing it.Overall it really is a shame as this was a missed opportunity. The engine is smooth as silk to play and looks stunning. If they had gone all out and made a true Sacred follow up with this tech, it would have been a truly amazing experience.

number of helpful: 38 of 52 people (73%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												As a fan of the first two games in the series, I had high expectations for the third installment when it came out.After the first few minutes of gameplay, I knew that the game wouldn't meet my expectations in any way. Deep Silver and Keen Games left out everything that made Sacred great. Instead of a huge open world with ridiculous amounts of sidequests and places to discover like in the first two games, Sacred 3 features a set of missions that have to be completed. The missions themselves are extremely linear, with only one route from beginning to end.Instead of an inventory and a huge pool of items, weapons and armor, there's... nothing. However the characters do have a few different weapons to choose from, with no weapon being necessarily better than the other, just different. The only loot you'll find is gold, which you can use to buy new skills.This is a shell of a game that features very little interaction other than killing stuff. No quests, no NPCs to talk to, nothing... just a few switches to press here and there. There is a bit of dialogue during the game. However that dialogue consists almost entirely of horrible attempts at humour and bad jokes... and I mean really bad, like kindergarten level bad.Although this game bears the "Sacred" title, it doesn't resemble Sacred in any way or form. I wouldn't have a problem with this game if they released it as some sort of spin-off or something. I mean it would still be a bad game, but with the "3" in the title, it drags the entire series through the mud.To me it seems like Deep Silver witnessed Blizzard's success with their overly simplified Diablo III and ordered Keen Games to do the same with Sacred 3 in order to make a hit game. That plan failed, although the game is fun a short while... but like Diablo III, it gets boring really quickly.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Oh my god, what has become of this fine hack&slay rpg game... it may be that i should have informed myself a little bit better, but i'm utterly disappointed. I saw the ad for the game today in steam and having played the first two iterations to the extend that afterwards i doubted my decisions in life, i had to have the game immediately. It was total news to me, that they even made another one, so that absolutely brightened my so far dull saturday. But it wasn't for long... So at first, everything i say is just based on the first mission and maybe i can bring myself to play it a little more, even if it was just for the money i spent, but i doubt it. But here are some warnings for some people like me, who are extreme fans of hack&slay rpgs like Diablo, Dungeon Siege, Torchlight etc. It plays more like a beat'em up, something like Devil May Cry or something similar, with some minor rpg "components" and here are some points why (and again, i haven't played much):1. No item dropsYep, thats right, no item drops, just some cash here and there and of course health etc. No stash, no backpack, but then again, what would you store in them...2. Straight as Hugh HefnerThis game is so linear, that i can draw you an exact replica of the first mission in ascii art (not really exact, but you'll get the picture):_________      __________        |___|         |____           |_______________  fin3. Missions?There seem to be no quests (and therefore no side quests of course), no maps, no running around tryin' to get every corner of the map light up, .... nothing. Just Mission 1 - 27 (don't know the actual number) which you have to wade through one by one.4. No in-game shops If you wanna buy something, you have to complete a mission and after the outro of the mission, you get to the lobby. In the lobby you have some (utterly ugly) menues, where you can level up, buy potions etc. No merchant, no blacksmith, just a plain menu between missions. I've seen 1,99€ indie games with way more innovative or at least cute versions for something like this (of course real in-game merchants is by the far the best way to go in my opinion).5. The HUDThe HUD looks like it comes straight from Street Fighter 2. If you liked the gothic style HUD from Sacred 2, you will be disgusted by it. The whole time you play the game, you just wait for a camera pan into 2d and a fiery text saying "ROUND 1 ... FIGHT". Okay, so far so bad, and by any means you could say i should have informed myself better, but to call this game Sacred frankly is ridiculous. This s not an action rpg, this is a 3d beat'em up game with some minor rpg elements! And the last thing i wanna add is, the voice over is totally idiotic and annoyed me after the first three sentences (and i liked the sometimes witty sometimes even a little cheeky humor of the first two parts). Everytime your guide popped up (of course in a comic style which reminded me of some classic games from the early 90s, which is totally fitting for a medieval style game...) i got so angry i started smashing the screen close to where her picture was, just to get some release. And i've been playing the game for 10mins at that time! So, in conclusion, i wouldn't recommend that game for rpg fans, especially the ones who like the classic hack&slay games like Diablo. I wouldn't recommend it for beat'em up fans either, there are far better games in that genre. If someone thinks this review is not justified and show me some footage or can persuade me otherwise, i will update this review if possible and give it another shot. I would be extremely thankful for something like this, since i paid way too much money for 20mins of gameplay... :(

												Do not be fooled by this game, if you are buying it because you enjoyed Sacred 1-2 and other Diablo-esque isometrics you will hate this game. Posted: January 23
												After reading all the negative reviews I was surprised to find this game as fun as I did. I have not played the first or second game in the series so I can not make a comparison. I actually liked the cheesy B grade narrative. This is an action RPG with a pretty interesting battle/combo system. I found it to work pretty good with an XBOX controller, since its more on the console side of things as far as game play goes, playing with KB/mouse it just felt clunky. To me it felt more like a simplified Shadow of Mordor in an isometric view. The game is easy to get into and relatively simple to pickup and get into. For a casual gamer its a blast, but I definitely can see anyone looking for substance, this definitely would not a good choice. I use the arcade style gameplay loosely here, in the respect it doesn't really feel like an arcade game to me, but the way in which you fight through hordes of bad guys then fight a boss as the end of each level, there is definitely an arcade style concept being used here. Sadly there dosnt seem to be any game saves, starting over at the beginning everytime you play is just wrong on every level. Also I get a black screen when starting up the game, can be fixed by alternating into window mode and back to fullscreen mode(alt+enter), not a big deal, but just goes to show that the game obviously still has bugs and some people may not be as fortunite to even be able to run the game at all.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												At this point I think it is pretty obvious that this game is not Sacred nor is it a true follow on to the Sacred series and is just a pathetic little money grab on the part of Deep Silver and Keen Games.That being said because it carries the name of the Sacred name it is hard to review it as another game....very few “new” games start off with [name of a franchise] 3.With that in mind, it almost seems like the developers made calculated and deliberate decisions to make the game as cheap, nasty and bad as possible. So bad in fact that it all borders on being malicious.  I can only assume that the developers had a meeting at some point to look at what Sacred 1 and 2 was and then made the decision to take everything that was not so good in 1 and 2 and make it even worse. Of course there where some good things in 1 and 2 as well they had a look and these and decided that the best thing would be to do exactly the opposite.  This is sure to win the hearts of the Sacred fans....oh wait. I guess they rather went out to win the hearts of some new fans.....why then call the game Sacred 3, why not something else, why go through the tedium of some small references to the previous games and it world when you could have done your own thing. Oh but it slipped my mind, this in not intended to be a good game the intention of this was to cost the developers as little as possible so they could put out a piece of software shaped faeces that they could sell for a quick buck. Speaking of the quick buck, as it it a pretty substantial buck, what does this actually buy you? You get a bunch ruler like linear levels, sewn together in a way that makes zero sense, half decent graphics, voice acting that would have been better if they were done by a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gorilla with a railroad spike through its head. The only thing that seems half fair considering the price it the download size of the game....it.....is...huge. This is probably the only thing that the developers Keen games achieved, I wouldn't have though that it would be possible for such a large download to translate to so little content, but they managed it. Just so the noteworthiness of this is not missed, games the size of single a CD translated to hundreds of hours of playtime, where they managed to get 4 DVD's worth of game to only last 10 hours, nice.... Speaking about the size, at the end of the credits it actually gives credit to some or other compression algorithm.....everyone should be well warned never use this as it is clearly beyond useless.It also struck me from the credit that there were probably 10 times more QA's involved with the game than anything else. They, as along with everyone else, were clearly not doing their jobs. In conclusion what you get with Sacred 3 is a shameless, pathetic money-grab turd dressed up in a Sacred frock. Done by a bunch of useless developers that should probably look for a different line of work. Hopefully the curse of Sacred will find them as well. (Curse of sacred: every development studio that has worked on a Sacred game has gone bust)

												As a HUGE fan of the Sacred series, who loves both Sacred 1 and 2 - this one is the worst of the lot!I have played only 1 hour of the game and finished only the 1st Boss on Warrior difficulty with some effort...I usually put some time into my reviews, but this is gonna be a short one. Here is my list with PROS and CONS:---=== CONS ===---(1) They put 80s american action movies humor (or something similar) in it which doesn't fit at all with the atmosphere of the old-feel melee and ranged fights...(2) Bad voice acting and the narrators are nagging you to rush through the game, instead of enjoy the game at your own pace and find the secret areas.(3) You have NO loot and cannot change your weapon either (I heard there are weapon and armor upgrades when you complete a mission, but it's not the same).(4) You gain XP and Gold and level up - but there is NO active skill tree, but you can select skills after missions.(5) When you roll - you can NOT roll into the directions you want (no matter what WASD keys or key combos you press), but always at the bottom of your screen - BOSS battles are impossible this way, except on the lowest difficulty (Warrior) with lots of effort... If you have a controller - absolutely try that - it should be better...(6) Base price is TOO DAMN HIGH - do NOT buy, unless you are 100% sure you want to try it or have it in your collection, don't buy the GOLD edition before trying it and aim for a 75% discount or more.(7) Everytime you ALT+TAB you have to press ALT+ENTER when you are back in the game to get it to Full-screen.---=== PROS ===---(1) Great graphics.(2) Great physics, animation and an okay art style.(3) Well optimised for PC - not heavy on computer resources like memory and CPU usage.I cannot really think of any other PRO right now - I will edit the review if I get more experience with the game or remember something else.I do not recommend buying this game...EDIT: After finishing the 2nd mission I see that there are other weapons and you can upgrade them, as well as if you don't press WASD in combat, the roll mechanic works 80% of the time in the right direction...

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Definitely not going to recommend this to anyone. If you want it for the sake of collecting the whole series, as was my own reason for getting it, go ahead. Just make sure you don't set any high expectations for this game, and most of all don't compare it to anything you know of the previous Sacred games.The in-game graphics certainly look better this time around than they did in Sacred 2, but the gameplay is not nearly as nice - from a fixed camera view, which can impede certain moves in battle, to doing the map one mission at a time. It's true that Sacred 2 was almost tedious in how large its open world map was, but comparatively I'd much rather go back to doing whatever missions I feel like doing at the time and be done with it.The upside of this is that Sacred 3 is definitely more competitive in nature now than its predecesor was. You need to reach checkpoints in the game versus saving whenever you want to and dying and respawning at a checkpoint will cost you some of your gold gathered in the mission.Overall, I really think it wasn't nearly worth the wait for the game to have been released and they could simply have ended the series with Ice and Blood. If you want to play a Sacred game, play Sacred 2: Fallen Angel.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Positive:- Pretty graphics- Good sound- Humor- Fun when playing CoopNegative:- Boring/repetitieve when playing solo- Unsatisfying leveling progress- False name branding.- False promotion art & trailer (see below)- Expensive compaired to valueThe game itself looks pretty, sounds good and is sprinkled with allot of funny oneliners.The user interface responds well, but everything from start to finish screams: "use controler not keyboard + mouse".Playing the game means fighting trough an instance like zone earning points/gold which you use to buy skills with after completing the the zone. So if you are looking for "loot" to satisfy your inner packrat munchkin you are out of luck. The playstyle is buttonsmashing in coop and is allot of fun to do with people you know. However when playing solo you will start to notice the repetitiveness of the buttonsmashing and the "rails" of this rollercoaster ride.The game is called Sacred 3 and as such it is part of a  brand line (the 3 in it's name would be a big hint)However where sacred 1 and 2 are open world games with multi tiered skill and loot gathering, Sacred 3 is more of a hack and slash on rails. Also the Seraphim player character which has returned in every sacred game does not look like the ones used in the previous game or even like the one used in the boxart and trailer!The above mentioned odities really give the impression that the publisher has been abusing the name and image of a fairly populair brand to  milk some extra cash.  This does not mean it is a poor game, as it is actually a fun game in short bursts, but when you look at similar games, the pricetag of Sacred 3 is really on the expensive part of the comparison scale.So if you are like myself who buys a game on faith and happy memories of previous installments.... then this is an excellent example of why you should always read reviews before buying.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												I wanted to like this game. It's a isometric action-fighting game of the type I really like. However, it's very linear, without the open world questing and the diversity of loot and skills that were in the previous games in this series. That can be ok since the various missions are fun, and the graphics/animations decent. I would have enoyed it enough to finish the game if it weren't for the ridiculous difficutly spikes you encounter when you reach the bosses at the end of each mission. Many of the bosses can kill you in just a few hits, and they frequently stun/trap you so you can't move. You have very little diversity in skills or attacks, so all you can do, regardless of the boss type, is brute force attach them while trying not to get hit. Not creative or fun. Given the poor dodge mechanic (see below), how hard bosses hit, and the lack of diversity of skills you have, the boss fights are immensely frustrating. When you die, you go back to the previous checkpoint. If you quit for a bit, you have start the entire mission over again. So the only way I could pass some of the bosses was to replay missions until I leveled up enough to survive them. Very frustrating. So, whereas I can play Grim Dawn, or Path of Exiles, or Torchlight, or any of the similar games all night and enjoy every minute, I find that I can play Sacred 3 for a short bit before I am so angry at a boss fight that I want to uninstall and curse the game's designers. I keep hoping it will get better, but it doesn't. There are some pros of the game:- Generally fun combat.- Decent graphics and animations.- Multiplayer works fine, though there aren't many people to play with.Cons:- No open world gameplay, or RPG elements, or any of the standard features of a Diabloesque game.- Linear missions, and entirely linear maps.- Horrendous difficulty spike when you get to the final bosses for each mission.- Bad dodge system. The doge system is essential for the boss battles, but you always dodge in the direction you are attacking, not the direction you are moving. The movement is with WASD, but the dodge direction is controlled by the mouse direction, same as your attach. So, as an archer, if you are shooting at a creature/boss and it charges you,  when you dodge you just roll right into whatever you are shooting at, no matter which way you are moving. You have to stop attacking and move the mouse away from your target before the dodge, which is too slow and defeats the purpose of the rapid dodge mechanic. Stupid.Mixed:- The story and voice acting. They designers went for over-the-top humor. Sometimes it's funny, but mostly it's lame, I bought this game for very little, so I got my money's worth. If you get it for a couple bucks, you'll probably wnjoy it enough for a bit, until you get frustrated and quit.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												First off, THIS GAME IS NOT SACRED. It has absolutely nothing to do with the other Sacred games, and please, for the love of sweet merciful crap, DO NOT EXPECT IT TO BE ANYTHING LIKE SACRED 1 OR 2. Abandon all hope of anything Sacred-esque being here. Disappointment abounds if you want this to be anything even remotely similar to Sacred. If you're a huge fan of Sacred and are/would be upset with #3 changing the formula, just don't buy it.*ahem*, now that I've said that...I enjoyed this game (NO NO WAIT, don't downvote me yet!) for what it was. It's dumb, hokey, cheesy, and mindless, but sometimes that's what you want. It doesn't take itself seriously AT ALL, and you have to be in for the ride or you'll hate the entire experience.In fact, the game I would most equate Sacred 3 to is the recently-redone Gauntlet. It's formulaic as all get out, linear as it can possibly be, button-mash-tastic, full of dumb humor, and complete with so-streamlined-I'm-embarassed-to-call-them RPG elements. And yet, it's fun.There's an overworld with scattered, self-contained short levels, there's a few classes to pick from, leveling up is handled automatically a la Diablo 3, there's no loot drops (but your gear levels up and gains new abilities), and then there's the dialog. Ohhh boy, the dialog. Sacred 3 apparently takes itself as a joke, with corny, hammy, 4th-wall-breaking, innuendo and pop-culture reference filled, joke-a-riffic dialog. Did I mention yet that you really need to go with the flow to enjoy this game? I was enjoying it, but I uttered more than a few "ugghhhh"s during my time.This is a great pick-up-and-play game, easily digested in small chunks. From the overworld, there's a series of story missions and little side mission things that you can pick from, and after 20 minutes at most of bashing and smashing, you're back at the level select screen and on to the next one. The side missions are the shortest of the bunch, lasting only 5 minutes at times, but they're rather essential as they help you level up (the recommended level on the story missions will quickly outrank you if you skip all side missions), and they give you additional potion slots of various types (health, energy, defense+, etc.). The story missions are quite a bit longer. They almost always include a pre-rendered cartoony cutscene with voice-actors hamming it up, they almost always include some sort of turn-this-wheel-6-times-while-enemies-spawn mechanic, they almost always include some sort of dodge-the-falling-stuff section, and they almost always include a big huge boss fight.I found the bosses to be quite fun. The combat itself is a blast in general, but the bosses up the ante. They almost always spawn other enemies around them, they usually have some sort of environmental hazard around them, and they're not too difficult as long as you can read their patterns. Don't expect to be frantically gritting your teeth while you're on the razor's edge of life or death, but you have to be somewhat coherent to surive.Speaking a little more on the combat, in the first few levels, you're just mashing attack over and over, but the combat evolves. Dodging becomes crucial, there are shielded enemies you have to bash, you can leap in the air and slam down on stunned enemies to insta-kill them, and there are spell attacks you have to interrupt before they can be pulled off. It's great. You'll be flipping around the arena, bashing a shield enemy and beating on him a bit before leaping to smash a faraway enemy in order to get out of harm's way. There are combat skills and such that get recharged with dropped energy, but they're nothing really special. Big slashes, aerial attacks, some chain lightning, shouting to stun enemies, etc. They can get you out of a pinch, but they're not enough stronger than regular attacks to be THAT useful. They recharge quickly, though, so don't feel like you need to save them for clutch moments.The only real weakpoint I experienced with combat is the QTE "restraining" mechanic. Essentially, if you've really been wailing on the boss or mini-boss, there's a little QTE section where you can mash a button for about 10 seconds to "restrain" them and do small bits of trickle damage the whole time. It's kind of pointless, since you could do just as much damage by just continuing to wail on them, and even though for the most part the enemies stop attacking you (in single player. Multiplayer they keep going), if your objective is to defend a crystal from some grenade-lobbing goblins, they'll keep attacking THAT while you're locked in the QTE. Luckily, you're never required to do the restraining, so I just opted to skip them most of the time. No big deal.All in all, the gameplay is fun, but rather basic. Slog along a linear path listening to cheesy, jokey dialog, slaughter some easy enemies and minibosses, turn a wheel 6 times, dodge some falling debris, and then kill a big boss. Do a couple short little side missions, and then rinse-repeat. In fact, repetition is a bit the name of the game here, almost as if it was intentionally designed to be that way. This game will take around 10 hours to beat if you don't grind or backtrack, but it's repetitive enough that you DEFINITELY don't want to do it in one or even two sittings. I've put 12 hours in, and that's over the course of maybe 4 different sessions. I can't recommend forcing yourself through much more than that at a time. You'll know when the game is starting to wear on you, and listen to that little voice in your head. Quit while you don't hate it, and come back later for more.The graphics here are a lot better than I was expecting. The geometry isn't Crysis-levels of complex or anything like that, but the texture work is phenomenal, the areas are all colorful and bright, and clearly a lot of work was put into designing unique "biomes" to progress through in the campaign. There's a bit of repetition, but nothing wearying. It's INCREDIBLY well-optimized, too. You could max this out at 1080P with a 4-year-old midrange card and still get 60ish fps.Sound and music are nothing worth remembering, and some of the little spirits you can bring along (they each have certain passive effects) have annoying dialog lines, but the worst offender here is the "help" text. When you're beating the crap out of enemies and not doing, for example, the leap-smash, expect to hear your spirit chime in with "helpful" advice every 5 seconds about how you should be leap-smashing. "Looking for peace? SMASH the enemy... with a hug!" Yeah, okay, I saw... "looking for peace? SMASH the enemy... with a hug!" Yeah, I SEE IT! "looking for peace?" AAGGGGGHHHHH! Luckily, you can turn that crap off in the options, which I did with vociferousness, and you should too. The mechanics of the game are not tricky in the slightest, so why they thought an overzealous "help" mechanic was needed is beyond me.Overall, if you (and a friend) are looking for mindless, slaughtering fun, and you're capable of taking everything for the joke that it is, you should have fun here. I know I did. If, however, you're a big fan of Sacred and were excited to see a 3rd one come out, RUN AWAY, there is nothing for you here.The big test is to watch a video on Youtube. Any 5 minute chunk of gameplay will be indicative of the whole game, and if that doesn't turn you off, check it out! It's worth the $6 I spent, in my opinion. Oh, also, USE A CONTROLLER.

Posted: August 6, 2014
												I haven't played much of the game yet but I can tell you that it's a real yawnfest. This isn't an action RPG game like any Diablo game or Torchlight game or Path of Exile, It's a beat 'em up game just like a host of other people are saying. No loot system only an upgrade system. You can unlock other weapons and upgrade them individually but it would require a lot of grinding to do so, since gold progression is relatively slow. The upgrade paths for each weapon don't differ from one another much either. It will come down to which one you think looks the coolest and that is the one you will use. You unlock 'combat' abilities very slowly and then you have the option to upgrade them much like your weapon/armor. But it's just too damn slow. You can upgrade it at lvl 4 and then you have to wait until lvl 12 and then lvl 20 for the next and lvl 33 for the next. Some have even bigger gaps it's really annoying. Why do I have to wait that long to do +20% more damage and or +50% radius or some♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's just bonehead design. Also these upgrades will cost thousands of gold. If it's a weak ability it will start at several hundred and increase to several thousands. But the better abilities in the game start at quite a lot and will cost you tens of thousands in gold combined just to finish the upgrade tree. Why would this game be such a grind fest? Especially when it's boring and repetetive in the first place. If you have to absolutely play this game do it with friends because solo is just boring and yes like many others have said the NPC chit-chat is obnoxious.Honestly the game insults my intelligence as will it yours. It does have bugs including getting stuck on invisible walls, bosses, corners and other♥♥♥♥♥♥that will force you to restart the entire level. Also much like people are saying, the game is not worth $50 or even $25. It's a $20 and under game. There isn't enough gameplay variety and it's a grind fest. Also if you like to make your own character you cannot, you can't even name your character they're just pre-made. It doesn't bother me but some people are really into customization and this game has very little, if any.I am playing the game on the hardest difficulty and it's just easy-peasy. Play it on the easiest... You would probably die in-game from falling asleep at the keyboard/controller.Steer clear of this. It's a complete consolized game. The graphics do not impress. They look a little better than Titan Quest graphics with better atmospheric lighting.

												I'd like to clarify some of the negative reviews.  This game "isn't that bad".  I won't say it's good, and I'd give it a neutral rating if possible.  It IS NOT WORTH full price.  But it has gone on sale for 3.75, and even been in the $1 tier of a Humble Bundle, and it is a fine/fun game for that price.This game's negative reviews are primarily given for one reason: Expectations.  It is disliked, even hated, because of what it isn't.What this game isn't:- Not a Diablo-clone (action RPG) like Sacred 1 and 2.  It can't really be considered much of an RPG at all.  It only has minor RPG elements.- Not made for keyboard and mouse.  It's made for a controller.- Not a high quality AAA title.  It has good graphics.  It has a terrible script.  It has intermediate voice acting.  The game mechanics are unoriginal.- Not worth $50;  probably not worth $15.What this game is:- Overhead beat-em up.- Minor RPG elements, like leveling up.- Designed for a controller- Designed with local co-op in mind. (I've not played it local co-op, so I can't speak to the quality of that experience)- Worth $3.75.This game will not be the next big thing in your library, but it could be a fun beat-em up to play with a friend.  A positive review on this game is gonna get some hate, because, like I said, this game is HATED for what it isn't.  It actually offends the fans that this game isn't what one would expect from a sequel to Sacred 1 and 2.But if this game wasn't called Sacred 3, it wouldn't be getting all this hate.  If it were called Sacred Citadel 2, or some obscure name like Arcania Heart, it would probably have much more positive reviews (except for the unreasonable price-tag).

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												I bought this during the sale for $3.74 and still cant quite bring myself to give it a thumbs up.  This game is a very simple, very linear, hack and slash.  You travel along on a terribly confined, predetermined pathway killing mobs.  At the end of each pre-defined pathway, there is a "boss" style mob.  You kill the boss mob and finish that pathway.  You move on the the next "pathway" and do the same thing again-over and over.  That is the game in a nutshell.  The scenery isnt engaging in the least and there arent any "drops"(random or otherwise) of items or equipment to make the game interesting.  All that drops is gold but I havent played long enough to know what the gold is supposed to be used to buy.  I may never play that long.  As far as comparing this game to previous Sacred games;  In many, many cases I have found that a new game in a series is pretty good but doesnt meet the expectations of those who played previous installments so the new installment gets a bad rap.  That is not the case with Sacred 3.  Sacred 3 deserves a bad rap all on its own merits.  Previous Sacred games are very busy games with a ton of things to do, tons of plot and sub-plot to remember story and quest wise, and lots and lots of interesting equipment drops and so on.  In truth, Ive always thought that previous Sacred games are TOO busy lol!  Anyway, Sacred 3 is not busy at all.  Sacred 3 is mindless in fact.  As I said above, you travel down relatively short corridors killing everything that comes at you, kill a boss and then you're done till the next corridor.  That is it.  Also, I think the charector scripts are supposed to be amusing but it comes of only as juvenile and silly.  Like another reviewer said; "Turn off the sound to make the game a little better".   Bottom line is that $3.74 is pretty cheap.  If you've got it to spare then buying this game probably wont be the worst decision that you've ever made.  BUT, should you chose NOT to buy Sacred 3, you wont be missing anything, I assure you.

I imagine a QA team asked to find bugs but told not to comment on actual gameplay. I imagine a producer with a "vision" of simplified play and nobody in a position to call bullsh*t. content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												First, this game has almost nothing to do with the previous Sacred Universe, neither in Story nor in Gamplay.The story is almost not present and is only an excuse to guide you over the map through the levels.The combat System is easy to learn and not complicated. You can take 2 Abilities on the missions which you also can alter between 3-5 between missions(so not much diversity). There are 3 Weapons per Class which are only different in their special ability. There is almost no such thing as Character development except the look of your Armour every few lvl ups. The Enemy types are repetetive and the level design is like a tube. After a few missions you get the feeling,you are playing the same lvl just with other skins and in another environment (which looks very pretty i have to admit). The Bossfights are somehow challenging at first try but then rather easy to accomplish. Sacred 3 is definitely a nice game for casuals and people who want to play with their friends a quick and simple coop game but for fans of the Sacred series and (i have to compare) Diablo like games, will be disappointed.After 9 hours or so i completed every mission and the day one dlc missions (5 in the Underworld).All in all this game is fun but has almost no replay vallue or longtime motivation and is never worth the 50€.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												If you are looking for a legitimate sequel to Sacred or Sacred 2, do not play Sacred 3.  The vast majority of the reviews for this game are simply based on disapointed fans that were expecting a true Sacred experience. If you can see past this, read on.If you are looking for a decent, linear hack and slash ARPG with some above average combat mechanics, its worth picking up on sale (under $20). There is not much character variety, but the actual enemy encounters and bosses are fairly well executed. The environments are nicely laid out with overall good art and have some unique mechanics to keep it interesting. I suggest playing on the hardest difficulty from the start to keep it challenging. Once you beat the game it unlocks a brutal difficutly called Deity for the hardcore. There is no loot in the game in the sense of dropped or collected gear or items. Instead they decided to unlock new abilities and weapons through leveling up. Its an interesting change of pace and makes the combat feel more like god of war than Diablo. Which can be a good thing if your looking for something more than a button masher. You will need to have good timing and strategy with your blocks, dodges and stuns to be successful in the harder stages. Play with a controller for the best experience. The dialogue is probably the worst in gaming history. If you want to constatly cringe and see just how bad it can get, prepare yourself for an interesting ride. You can easily turn off voice and you wont notice the text since it does not affect the game at all. The game can be finished in about 10 hrs and other than trying to max out character abilities or playing on higher difficulties, there is little replay value. The Orc playable character DLC is worth picking up for a couple bucks. Hes strong and has some fun, skill based abilities. If you are an action RPG fan that is fine with more linear console style gameplay, its worth playing.

												This is the first game that I've bought on Steam where I want my money back. I have dozens of games I've not even played and never plan to and I don't want to get a refund for them - I know that if I play them I'll enjoy them and that I'll have paid for that privilege. Not this though. Hell no. This game fails at every level.Firstly, it's not Sacred 3. It's a completely different game by a completely different development house. I've heard that they have been working on this since 2010, so I don't understand how they could have failed to have any kind of focus group or input from any gamers who had played the originals in producing this item. It's not an RPG, it's has no lastability, no in-depth world, no enjoyable storyline or characters, no exciting loot drops or character builds, none of that.Ok, so let's take it at just what it is, a new hack'n'slash rather than a sequel to an awesome game or two - this has no character variation and very little variation in the mobs, a short game world, no replayability, dreadful script spoiling good voice acting, but it does have very vibrant graphics and fair sound. Controls are poor with keyboard and mouse but fair with a controller. There's certainly a lot of action in each fixed arena you fight in, but it doesn't change, even the boss fights are mediocre. 4 hours into the game I'd given it a good try, struggling to find some nugget of gold in this midden heap. It was halfway complete and I didn't want to play it ever again.If this was released on a phone or tablet for $2.99 I could see someone buying it and playing it once before deleting it, knowing that that was what they were expecting, but £40 or $60 or whatever it is, after 4 years in the making??? I want my money back.
