content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												At the time of writing this, Sacred 3 has a 'Mostly Negative' rating on Steam. I honestly can't think of a game I've played recently that is 'mostly negative' other than this game, and that includes quite a few garbage titles acquired through greenlight bundles and the like. 'Mostly negative' is an extremely low rating for Steam, frankly, it puts the game in the same kind of expression as one would describe taking a shortcut through an alleyway to discover a dumpster fire.Or I guess in this case, someone wrote 3 on the dumpster fire. Anyway: Sacred 3's two biggest problems are likely that it was launched at an AAA price-tag and that it is marked a sequel to Sacred 2, instead of a sequel to Sacred Citadel, the latter being a side-scrolling beat 'em up but from what I've read far closer to Sacred 3 than Sacred 2 was. The game is now $15 and I was kind of astounded to see it in the dollar tier of a recent humble bundle, so I picked it up.Anyway goods and bads:+Beautiful, AAA level graphic quality for a game of this genre. Tons of scenic variety, lots of beautiful details. I really can't overstate how nice the graphical and aesthetic work is here.+Fun, frantic, high energy combat with some RPG trappings... Reminds me a lot of small dungeon WoW, but more frantic. Contary to other reviews, you can and do change up your skills, weapons and some other minor stuff, but it's not anywhere near a RPG really.+Lots of fun boss fights+Excellent, abundant voice acting. Your character, your weapon "spirit", your telepath and usually the boss of the dungeon all talk. Gives the game a lot of personality that changes up as you play.+Good score-Incredibly lacking in enemy variety for game length. Mind-bogglingly so. They put together more models and skins than actual enemy types. The enemies you do fight have personality, but you fight the same guys over and over.-Combat gets repetitive due to lack of enemy variety, game can be a bit grindy-Some visual elements don't translate well, and often enemies winding up a tell can't be seen, or they're allowed to attack from offscreen, or there's just too much stuff constantly flooding in to move properly. Game is missing that last bit of polish and gets real janky at times.-Game has SOME RPG trappings, but not nearly enough and a lot of it doesn't make sense. There is only one kind of random drop in the entire game, everything else is scripted and often nonsensically. The talent trees are simplified, and you only have 2 skills with four other inputs at a time - attack, dodge or block, light art, heavy art, bash and execute - and the two you can change aren't staggered well so you don't end up switching a lot. Most of the weapon spirits aren't well balanced, so again, you tend to get stuck with certain set ups for long stretchs of the game.-Your telepath who feeds you instructions is usually charming, and the voice actress does good work with what she is given, but in some cases they didn't record enough dialogue or re-use/repeat dialogue way too quickly. It can get really annoying at times. Again - that last bit of polish.-Story and humor have tone all over the place. Some of the jokes are just awful. While most of the voice acting is excellent, the "big bad" is poorly written and just sounds way too hammy. The game is about 25% more shlock than it needs to be.Anyway, is Sacred 3 great? Well, it has great graphical assets, which I assume the original pricetag was informed by. The rest of the game is ... Okay? Good in parts, but usually just above average, kinda terribly unpolished in patchs. It's certainly not the 'mostly negative' hobo in a dumpster fire it sounds like. I can totally understand people who paid $50 being upset at it, but for the current asking price or out of a bundle, I think it's pretty okay. It should have been a much better game, and titled Sacred Citadel 2, and it's a real shame I doubt anyone will ever do anything ever again with the excellent art assets.

												This game had alot of potential but didnt' really live up to it.+The graphics are good. The backgrounds and character models are all great.-The voice actors are good, I recognize many of their voices from other games. However the lines and accents they are given are pretty terrible. content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I've been a member of the Steam community for over 5 years now. This is the first review I have ever written. YES, this game is THAT bad. First let me say that I really enjoyed Sacred 2, which is why I commited to pre-purchasing this game. The character classes in this game don't really differ from one another. Yes, this one has a sword and that one an axe, and then another with 2 swords. With the exception of the bow, they pretty much do the same thing. A short arc swing in front of you and the ability to use a bash (no shield required or available) which also is a short arc swing in front of you. You can hold down the button to "charge" a bash to give it some range but it's still a very weak attack and all but useless except to interrupt enemies who are engaged in any long duration ability use. In this game you will find yourself going from map to map using the same abilities over and over against enemies that vary little. The terrain is tediously boring and there is no room to explore. You go the way they want you to go or you can go back the way you came. The weapon varieties are laughable as they all pretty much do the same thing with very little difference among them. Leveling up is a major let down. No stats to increase, no growth of your character. But every few levels you get the option to upgrade a weapon or one of the very limited abilities you want. You cannot switch armor, you can only upgrade what you have when you reach the appropriate level and graphically it is such a let down as there is no real change to how it looks. The voice overs from "weapon spirits" are laughably horrible. The plot is weak and shallow and all but non-existent. Online play: Your character will NOT be unique. Your Seraphim will be exactly like anyone elses Seraphim of the same level and since each class has only 1 viable weapon choice, (the others are just filler weapons that won't do as well) then you will each have the exact same weapon and be doing the same 2 or 3 maneuvers over and over until you finish a map. Gameplay: Run through each map killing whatever set monsters they throw at you until you reach the end of the map. Hit the portal then go to the next similar map again killing whatever set monsters they throw at you until you reach the end. Every 4th or 5th map there is a BOSS fight at the end. Boring combat of dodging predictable boss attacks and hitting them in the butt until dead. Then hit the portal and be prepared for yet another map of absolutely unexciting combat. This game lacks any variety, sense of character uniqueness, or flash. What you do in the first 2 minutes of game play is exactly what you will be doing after 3 hours of game play, it doesn't change or get any better. It is the biggest let down I can ever remember purchasing.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Sacred 3 is arguably one of the biggest disappointments in my personal gaming history.  The sequel to its predecessors leaves little to the "Sacred" title series, as it is far different--the "red-headed step child"--the "oddball" of the three.  Unlike the first two games in the hit series, Sacred 3 is a very linear action RPG, and the term "RPG" is held very loosely and walks a very thin line.The graphics in the game are beautiful, detailed, and the environment rich and fairly interactive, and the combat is flowing and can bring a fun challenge, but it simply is not enough to save this game from the broken chains of what made this franchise so popular.  In Sacred 3, there is no exploration--so put away your maps, and every bit of directional video game intuition you have (or think you have).  Everything is based on a standard, linear, pre-planned map you choose from an overview screen after each level, with no way to go but "forward", and the occaisonal random dead-end so that you can loot that very special treasure chest.Speaking of loot, this game does not offer loot in terms of items, but only health and energy (used to cast your TWO powers you are able to use at any one time) and gold.  I repeat:  Loot DOES NOT DROP from mobs or foes that you so diligently vanquish like a good little hero.  Instead, weapons and armor (you only use one of each) are "unlocked" when the game says so--usually when hitting a milestone character level or completing a specific storyline mission.As far as storyline missions go, the story is decent and follows a logical path, but the side quests seem out of place (even for side quests), and the only objective you are ever given is "kill them all"...all of them...again...and again.  And if you are too low for the recommended level of a certain quest you want to trudge through, guess what?  Tough luck.  Keep replaying missions until you ARE able to get to that level to defeat those quests.While I somewhat enjoy the fact that you must acheive certain character levels to unlock weapons, armor levels, and abilities, the idea in its own entirety seems hollow.  You loot gold, gold buys you skill and weapon upgrades, and you set those upgrades as active skills that you can use (you use one light skill and one heavy skill)--and normally when you find the best combination of skills, you stick with those, and the endless piles of gold you can grind out may as well be valued as worthless pebbles on the ground.There is no character development, other than the "customizing" of your two skills, weapon slot, and armor slot--and they all fall onto a linear path.  There is no developing character stats, no adding talents, no feats, no kind of character traits, no type of roleplaying element whatsoever.  And if you have seen one area-of-effect skill, you have seen them all.  The characters, while they each have their own personalities, offer very little difference in comparison to each other.Without a doubt, the game's strong point is its combat and its cooperative playstyle--and it gets old--quickly.  The hack 'n slash button mashing is very similar to the Dynasty Warriors style, with combos, shield breaking, knockdowns, executions, etc.  There isn't much combat variation throughout the entire game, and the fun feel you may have when starting to play the game quickly wears off after a multitude of repetitive side quests.  It's always fun to play with a buddy or three, which is what Sacred 3 offers--and is fantastic.  The difficulty scales to the number of players in the game, and while this CERTAINLY makes the game more enjoyable, there is very little synergy between characters, and it leaves you to visualize a bland series of attacks and abilities being randomly used on the map.Another neat addition to the game is the use of "weapon shards", which is just another item the player can equip to his or her character--and these shards will add a buff to you and/or your party members, but also offer a debuff.  For example, the Vampire weapon shard gives you the ability to lifesteal on hit against most enemies you will face, with the drawback of making health orbs (health pickups) less effective.  However, these weapon shards, as well as all of the other voices, in Sacred 3, leave most normal people wanting to pull out their hair and throw on music in the background to drown out the INCREDIBLY annoying dialogue.  You are led and directed by a female named Aria, who helps you constantly on your journey--and you often wish she doesn't--as she jokes about every area and situation your party goes into.  Your weapon shards talk back to you, and after every single fight and combo you go through, you are battered with really terrible one-liners by a mage that consistently hits on you, or a vampire that has a "drinking" problem (funny, right?  not when you hear it 100 times...in one level), or a dragon that is scared of everything and literally SCREAMS in fear after every fight.While the graphics are extremely beautiful, and the combat can be fun at most times--especially on crazy boss battles--it does NOT make up for the features taken out from the legendary Sacred 1 and 2 games...features that, according to the developers, "made the game worse", which is a sorry excuse for laziness and flat-out burglarly using generic propaganda with the word "Sacred" in their game title.  If you are expecting Sacred 3 to be a part of the Sacred games you loved so dearly, then STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME.  It is NOT that game, unfortunately.  If you go into the game with an open mind, like I did, after reading awful previews and reviews saying this exactly, it can be fun for some hours--and then you can write a disgruntled review like I am, expressing the sadness and anger of being conned by the developers and wishing you had done a little more research before purchasing.  In short, Steam asked me if I recommend this game--Yes or No.  They did not give me a **** NO option, so a simple "No" will have to suffice.  Stay away.

												I am not recommending for immediate purchase, but perhaps a future purchase, and here is why:To begin with, I must admit that I was excited when I first heard of the title as I am a fan of the Sacred series. I became a little more skeptical after reading about some of the changes made (no longer open world / no more signifigant variety of loot), but I figured I was up for a new hack and slash experience, and it's Sacred III after all (What could go wrong?). In the end, I am rather more disappointed in that it feels more like a combo-game of Sacred and Dynasty Warriors, in the sense that it is interesting at first, but after a while (3-4 hours) I personally find myself getting bored. Graphics are solid, gameplay is fun, and the comedic charm is a matter of personal perspective as always. However, in the end, I must admit I have little interest in playing through on all the different characters, only becasue it feels like it might be a drag. I tried them all out through the first mission (apparently necessary at this point if you want to take them into the multiplayer feature) just to see which I liked the best, and after picking a favorite have decided to complete the game (whatever that might mean) with this character and then move onto something else.The biggest disappointment for me was how the whole image of competing with others for treasure was hyped (IMHO) and all it seesm to add up to is getting a little more gold / exp and the completion of a mission. I have no trophy display case or homebase to improve with all my glorious and hard-fought loot, rather I get a screen that is like, "Hey, you killed the most guys, good for you, here is an extra percent to add to the pile."Now all that said, if there was a signifigant increase to the amount of RPG / Loot /Upgrading side of the equation, whether through a solid patch, or more likely an expansion or DLC, I might consider playing the game further, but for now, I would recommed a purchase only if you are a fan of the Dynasty Warriors type experience, looking for a bit of a time sink, and the game is marked down for sale (think 50% off or more).

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												Please turn the wheel 6 times to continue reading this review....If you are a fan of the Sacred series, just avoid this game entirely as it will likely lead to depression.  While the name of the game is Sacred 3, it really is just a basic hack and slash game similar to the Sacred Citadel title except priced at $50.  If you were hoping for an open world full of quests, loot, and character customization look elsewhere as this has none of that.Should you be able to disregard the name and what Sacred 3 really should have been, you might find some enjoyment here.  However, it is not likely to justify price tag.  I will briefly cover some of the pros/cons of the game.  For reference, I have finished the campaign entirely with the DLC character and have seen all the game really has to offer.PROSSoundtrack - Though it is not amazing and lacks something as epic as Blind Guardian's concert from Sacred 2, the music is fine and has, at times, a dark mood that should fit the game.Stage Art - Some of the stages look good and there is some variety in their look.CONSNo Loot - With the exception of weapon spirits, gold, and health/power orbs, you will find no loot.  Weapons and armor are dropped and upgraded on a set schedule as you finish particular stages.  Sadly, weapon spirits are often not particularly useful with the exception of a few.  I honestly can deal with no open world but no loot is a low blow.Repetitive Gameplay/No Open World - You just enter stages from an overworld map.  Here is what virtually all main stages look like.  Enter -> Fight Group -> Open Gate -> Fight Group -> Dodge Traps/Projectiles -> Fight Group -> Find Key (on enemy or in chest nearby) or turn switch (always 6 times) -> Boss.  Smaller stages will have just 2-3 small groups of enemies or 5 waves in an arena style.  You will probably find yourself fighting the enemies like so Regular Attack -> Bash (when icon appears above enemy) -> Combat Art -> Repeat Until Dead.  If you want to test out the A button on your XBox controller, this will do the trick though.Little Customization - You can select 2-3 combat arts for each of the two slots.  You can upgrade these using gold at set intervals.  Often you have no choice on what upgrade you get.  In other cases, you have two options.  In my experience, the combat arts I got later in the game were not powerful enough to bother with.  I used the same initial ones throughout the game.  The same applies to the weapons.  The later ones were not powerful enough and thus were not used.  After trying a few other characters, the feel is similar with one direct combat art and another that does AoE damage.  If you are looking to create wonderful builds then look elsewhere.Length/Replayability - Even when spending some time repeating levels, I beat the campaign in about 8 hours.  If you played straight through on normal difficulty, I would imagine it could be done in 5 or 6 hours.  The DLC appears to add about an hour to the game.  While you can continue to play the game after the final boss, the incentive is just to level up which, as stated, seems fairly pointless as you do not get much to really make your character better.Technical Glitches - Often I have had the game change resolutions or exit full screen mode for no reason.  I have had it crash several times.  It also has caused a popup saying I lack the memory to continue playing.  I am running the game on a laptop with 8GB of RAM and a 2GB graphics card.  I can run games like Skyrim on max settings and this should not be any more difficult to run.  So it is clearly not optimized and has bugs which may never be fixed.HIT OR MISSDialogue - Honestly, I believe they tried to hard to be funny.  However, some lines and interactions might amuse you.  Overall, it seems forced but it might depend on your sense of humor.In summary, avoid this game like the plague if you want something like Sacred.  You might consider Torchlight 1/2 or Grim Dawn instead.  You could also wait for Unbended (by the original designers of the Sacred series).  Even Diablo 3 is a much better option given it actually has loot.  If you want a mindless button masher, I'd still wait for a price drop as much cheaper titles (such as Castle Crashers) provide just as much in terms of replayability and honestly Deep Silver/Keen Games does not deserve support for what was clearly a quick money grab using the Sacred name.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												UPDATE: You may want to search around and find out what happened to the devs of Sacred 1 & 2. Even if you don't care about those earlier titles. It's has nothing to do with the gameplay and as such I won't change my review. But Deep Silver (who the devs lost the franchise to) is now on my blacklist for being real life vilains.I enjoy this game, had it a different title to ease minds and a 20$ price tag I'd recommend it as is.Yes the levels are really linear but I wouldn't call them boring, they challenge you in a variety of ways that will have you adapt your gameplay. The options you get aren't that limited as many make it sounds. The cut-scenes are well-polished, the dialogues are funny, I like the different characters (heroes and vilains alike) and they are supported by a more-than-decent voice acting.About the franchise: I don't care much. I played the 1st and 2nd titles as time wasters while waiting for game able to outshine D2 (or at least come close). You probably know that already by now (everyone seems to be mad about it), Sacred 3 is a very different game. But it has nothing to do with the fact I do not recommend it. However, if it bothers you, well, that's another reason why you should stay away from it.To me the root of the problem is that it wasn't meant to be played on PC, it's a really poor port of what seem to be a good console game. From the settings to the controls it really doesn't fit (yet). Some examples:- It's easy to lose sight of your cursor and on high difficulty it often means insta death. It wouldn't have been hard to design one that is easier to spot.- Pressing space to dodge (if you still use dodge that is, you should get block) will have your character rolling toward your cursor even if you were moving in the opposite direction. It's very unintuitive. That also could easily be fixed.- Limited options due to the initial target (console).- Zero way to use the keyboard to chat, you'll have to use the in game voice over IP that everyone mutes so it won't be much use. Unless you playing with friends using skype, TS, ... you won't be able to say anything to your "co-op" partners.On that last note, I wouldn't call it a co-op game. Multiplayer? Check. PvE? Check. Cooperation? Very little. It doesn't mean it's not fun to play with others, but you do not need to cooperate.TL;DR: Different from Sacred 1 & 2. Good casual arcade time waster that can even be a bit challenging at times. Poor PC adaptation. Way too expensive for what it is.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												I came in to this game expecting more along the lines of Sacred 1 and 2. I watched the intro movie, it seemed similar as well. Stupidly enough, i did not watch any reviews before getting the game. The two things I loved about sacred were the open world, where one could go whereever one wished, and the equipment. There's something gratifying about finding that new special weapon, or upgrading it just so.Then there's Sacred 3.  Linear storyline. No open world. You are driven from room to room in "mission" like episodes instead of picking up a bunch of quests and picking and choosing. There is no loot. None. Nothing. Zilch.The weapon upgrades you can get are once every 4 levels from what i gather.The hack and slash is still there, the combat is fun, but this is not Sacred. Sure, you can pick from the original classes (still no gender choice of course), You play in Ancara, and the battleskills are still there. But this is not the game i thought i bought.The story so far seems... an odd mix between an attempt at comedy and a tacky storyline. I might play on, I'm not sure on that yet, just to see how it continues, but so far? This is not Sacred 3. This should bear a title like Heroes of Sacred, or some such alternatively named game, to indicate it deviated from the original that much.On a whole, severely disappointed with what i thought would be an awesome title.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												LOAD OF S.H.I.T! THIS IS NOT SACRED GAME ANY MORE....I'm really disappointed in this game.A few months ago, I pre-ordered X Rebirth on steam, and received a console-recycled, bug-ridden, unplayble mess. I promised myself that I would never buy a game again without waiting for reviews.But I was fooled again, blinded by the pre-order bonuses of Sacred 3, and the fond memories I had of S1 & S2. S3 is pretty, but that's it. The controls are clearly made for a console. On PC, you move your character with WASD, and you have only 4 attacks/skills (2 on mouse, keys 1 and 2). You evade with space, but have no control on it's direction. Lot's of destructible elements, but you'll often have to strike 3 times before one of your swings actually hit what's right in front of you. All of that make for clumsy control of your character on PC.Don't expect much of character personnalisation, either. There is no cosmetic or gender choices to make, and only 8 skills per class.There's also a ever-present comedic routine, fun for the first 10 minutes, but it gets old very fast. But the one thing I can't forgive, is that there's no loot. Sacred 3 is a Hack&Slash without loot.Imagine Diablo 3 without items, choice of weapons, dumbed down controls and with only a handful of skills. Would you like to play it?TL,DR: Never, ever buy a game right when it's release, and Sacred 3 is a fraud for using the Sacred licence.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												I didn't play Sacred 1 & 2 yet, so unlike many other reviews, I'm not comparing it to the previous titles (as I understand it's not made by the same company anyway, someone bought the rights). My judgement here is based purely on the games own merrit. The game has good graphics, controls and general gameplay are O.k. but nothing special (except the evade command, it throws you in totally random directions and as such is quite terrible). I also would say the voice acting isn't bad... but the actual scripts the voice actors had to read are REALLY REALLY bad. I feel sorry for them. Whoewer wrote the scripts has no idea what a fantasy RPG entails. It's simply terrible. You defeat some enemys and as you pick up loot you hear stuff like (and I quote) ''Sexy!'' or ''O baby!'' or ''Feels good!''. There is also no atmosphere in the game worth mentioning.If you want to even remotely enjoy the game, turn the character voices OFF! You also might want to considder turning off the games music and using your own for better atmosphere.After I turned the voice acting and music volume OFF and used a atmospheric black metal compilation to give it some dark atmosphere, the game was MUCH more anjoyable. That said, I would never recommend it for the current regular price of 14 Eur. The game is very linear, very repeatitive and feels in some ways like a cheap mobile game. Personally I bought a hard copy for 3 Eur and I still at times feel it wasn't woth it - for me. Buy only if you're O.k. with using your own music as you play.FINAL VERDICT: 3/10 (or if you follow my suggestion for better ambience: 5/10).p.s.: if you have a limited budget and want a good but cheap action-RPG, try Path of Exile (free to play) or buy Victor Vran when on sale. Judging by the reviews, the older Sacred titles are most probably a much better pick as well, specially when on sale).

												I would absolutely advise against this game, especially if you've played EITHER of the first two. This game is not Sacred. It just isn't. It's some crap hack'n'slash game that doesn't look, feel or play like any of the Sacred games. It's not the same style, it doesn't even feel like it's the same world. The game isn't just different, it's also bad. The combat is literally spamming a button until a big enemy spawns, then using an ability, then returning to the same routine. I was excited about Sacred 3 as soon as I heard it was coming and now that it's out it has no similarities with the original. I wouldn't be so annoyed if they had just called it something other than Sacred, as it stands this does not fit into the "trilogy" if you even want to acknlowledge this as being part of the Sacred series.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												Not quite the game I expected, but still quite fun.  I admit I haven't played the first 2 Sacred's, which is probabaly why I am giving this game a recommend.  From what I hear the first 2 were open world Diablo like Hack and slash games.  Sacred 3, they changed the game to being a more arcade type hack and slash game, similar to Gauntlet.Some of the games design doesn't make much sense.  Its an arcade style game, where as you kill the enemy, they will drop HP and action type regen potions?  The action is quite outlandish for an RPG styled game, where you get skills that make you jump across the screen and butt flop on the enemy to kill them.   Instead of an open world styled game like Torchlight or Diablo, instead you are put into on the rails played short missions, usually ending with a boss of some kind to finish the mission.  The game does allow for Co-op play, which seems easy enough to get a game, but you must finish your first mission (The hardest one I found so far in the game), before it will allow you to play in Co-op, which may leave some players behind.Unlike other games, where there are loot drops, or you earn gold in the game to spend on gear, you pick up gold, but at the end of the round, all that gold disappears (???) no idea why, and you get a seemingly static amount of gold for finishing the mission.  You can then use that gold given to you in the end to upgrade your skills and weapons, but there are no skill trees or really anything in terms of different equipment to save for.  And the skill and equipment upgrades are limited to level unlocks.    The characters in the game also dish out tons of badly voice acted one liners, similar to Duke Nukem, but not as good.  I have played 2 male characters so far, and both are constantly hitting on the female "narrator" in the game, with really cheesy pickup lines, topped with super bad voice acting that kills the humour. All the bad being said.  The game does have a AAA title type polish to it, and plays well.  Just don't expect the next Diablo/Torchlight/Van Helsing.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Sacred 3 is a very good game. It's a beat-em-up brawler similar to Gauntlet just better, although that's probably a matter of taste. The only thing this game is not is Sacred.I am not aware of any other game on Steam that received as many negative ratings as Sacred 3 has. The reason for this are unfulfilled expectations. That's because Sacred 3 has nothing to do with Sacred 1 or Sacred 2. The game is neither an open-world game nor a role-playing game and the only thing Sacred 1 and Sacred 2 share with Sacred 3 is the name. If you can accept that and you like hack and slay games Sacred 3 is a very enjoyable game.Pros:- nice graphics, beautiful landscapes- character specific weapons, armor, special attacks- weapon upgrades- armor upgrades- special attacks (upgradeable)- 15 diversified levels in the main game- good DLCs- good music- co-op- multi-player, lobbies are currently full (October 2015)- co-op in combination with multi-player (two co-op, two mp)- you only collect gold (which keeps you from searching for scrolls and any other hidden stuff)- very easy to join games- you can join or leave games at any time- four difficulty levels (last difficulty is accessible after first play-through)Cons:- it's not Sacred- leveling up can get tiresome. Once you reached level 30 it takes a lot of time and fighting to collect the necessary experience points to level up further.There are dissent opinions about the dialogs in the game. Please take into considerations that the game supports different languages with different translations and speakers. During your journey you are accompanied by Aria, a telepathic, informing you about upcoming events, enemies dangers, areas, etc. She keeps talking all the time and at least in German her voice acting is great. Then you can select a god that inhabits your weapon, providing some special abilities. The selected god keeps talking too. The gods talking strongly reflect their diverse personalities and they tend to exaggerate.Dialogs are often childish with a strong use of youth slang. They tend to not take the game seriously and are very grotesque. It's the grotesqueness that makes the dialogs funny again, provided you have the right sense of humor.I like them, especially Aria is great in German.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												Sacred 3 is not perfect, but it's enjoyable enough for me to recommend it.Bear in mind that this game is an isometric brawler and very different in style from the previous two main chapter of the Sacred series. With that out of the way, I'll try and judge it on its own merits.I finished the main campaign, the two DLC areas and the secondary missions in little more than 12 hours. I took some time to grab a couple achievements and explored most levels to find hidden chests, so a straight playthrough of the main campaign will be a few hours shorter. However, the variety of classes and the scaling difficulty (difficulty 4/4 is unlocked when you beat the game, so it works as a New Game +) make the game interesting to replay.Story is pretty straightforward: defeat the evil boss and all his henchmen. For the same reason, the setting isn't really that interesting, story-wise, as it only works as a selection of different setpieces where action takes place.The humour is very hit and miss: I didn't enjoy cutscenes that much, but I appreciate that every character has specific voice-acted lines to reacts to the most important milestones of every level.Gameplay is simple but enjoyable. Two main attacks (light and heavy), a defensive move, three active skills (which can be selected from a pool) and 6 consumable items. The game however throws many enemies at you and it mixes them so that you need to pay attention to all their attack patterns. Jumping from one enemy to another to neutralize the most immediate thread is fast and rewarding. Enemy selection is adequate: every major campaign stage one or two new enemies are introduced (or they get new abilities), so you keep facing different challenges as you progress.Boss fights are generally well crafted, with many powerful and flashy moves and some environmental hazards thrown in. Especially the two DLC boss fights are quite challenging. While levels are mostly corridors (with a few exceptions), every major level has at least an optional path with a miniboss and an extra chest. The game tries to mask the linearity by having you explore dark woods, climbing towers and breaching walls, for instance. The setpieces are very different from each other, colorful and with some impressive architecture. Camera mostly works and will help you appreciate the scenery while you move from a fight to the next one, again contributing in making the game feel less linear.My main problem with the game is that there is barely any customization (apart from weapon spirits, which give a buff and a debuff and mix gameplay up a bit, but are so unreliable to unlock and level up). You can pick a loadout, but there is no real loot. Every mission will unlock a new powerup or a new item, so there is no thrill in opening chests and defeating bosses. It's not loot, it's just progression unlocks.Multiplayer works mostly fine. I've had people joining my games during the majority of my sessions and everything seemed smooth. I experienced lag once or twice while joining other games myself, but I suspect it's on my side.All things considered I would recommend this game. I will probably jump in again to clear a few more achievements and to try out another class or two. It's definitely not Sacred and it's not a groundbreaking game, but it's enjoyable.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												There are no spoilers in this review.To begin,-This game is a completely different genre from it's predecessors.-The mechanics are more suited for handheld console play (think PSP/ 3DS/ mobile app). I would even go so far to say that this PC port felt more like an afterthought.Game complexity: I am not against grinding as a game mechanic, because there can be good grinding games where you're constantly on your toes, and then there's bad ones. Sacred 3 falls under the latter - I fell asleep while clearing mobs because there's virtually no challenge - press button, monster dies. HP/Mana management? Choosing the right equipment for the right fights? Fret not, you are released from that burden in this game. </s>Replayability: The only reason to try out other characters is to see their skills. You can get the same experience from watching a YouTube video of the characters, then you're back to facing the same levels all over again.I wrote this review having owned a PSP myself, and played hack-and-slash games such as Dynasty Warriors, DMC3, God of War, Ryse, and many others. Avoid this game at all costs - even if it was free, your time could be spent on other games instead.

content:

												Why so much rage? Disappointed much?When getting this during a sale, and approaching it without overblown expectations, this is quite a decent game - not great, but not as bad as some reviews indicate it to be.If you like fast-paced button smashers/monster bashers, and look at a few hours of simple, relaxing gameplay, this is an OK game in the vein of Gauntlet and similar (Dungeon Siege without loot), with some decent graphics. Don't expect much RPG content, though.Most boss fights are doable (some quite hard, though - especially the Dark Seraphim), and tbh I found the worst part (except for the Dark Seraphim) to a map with the spike traps around Level 20, where you start pretty far back when you die.Replayability, though, is so/so at best.Worst game ever, as some reviewers have stated? Not by a long long distance - there are literally hundreds of games worse than this.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												The in-depth custumization and character development, as well as massive world with many side quests in Sacred 2, which we had hoped from Sacred 3... dissappointment is really what it it. If you are looking for a massive open game like Sacred 2, this isn't it. This is litterally nothing like Sacred 2, except the fact that you only get to pick a few characters and no real customization.They took a whole new approach, and tried to tap into the more action combat gameplay. Although this game does that quite well, it is just like many other games of its kind, but less imaginative. Graphics are pretty decent and action combat is alright. Sacred 2 voice overs were actually pretty decent, but Sacred 3's is absolute terrible. They tried to half heartedly make the game funny, which turned into pathetic. The best voice over would be the first battle spirit you come across. He is quick witted, funny, and enjoyable to listen to. Problem was that the game made very little indication as to who was actually talking. Pretty much I had no idea it wasn't the character I was playing as talking for a bit.Gameplay is average at best, boring as heck at worst. Every single mission basically plays out the same. Waves of bad guys with varying abilities you HAVE to use to even kill them. Bosses with all the same basic skills, then repeat. Pretty simple really, if they have a shield above their head, you have to knock it away. Otherwise you just keep moving and killing. Like Dynasty Warriors, but not as cool.The absolute worst part of the game, is the variety. Every single hero plays exactly the same. Sure you can pick two skills, but most of the skills are about the same. Some are a complete waste to even pick, which lowers the variety even more. You can pick your weapon, but they are very similar so it won't even matter much. For the price tag, I would say this game is totally not worth it. There are many MANY games out there that have more depth to them for a fifth the price. I would only get this game if it is on super sale for 75% off or more.

												I get it that the die hard fans of the first two games are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off that this is so different, but seriously this game is fun.  The RPG elements are tuned down, but frankly sometimes you dont actually care to spend hours tweaking attributes and juggling gear scores...   Sometimes you just want to dive in and murder the crap out of hordes of monsters!!   This game is very enjoyable, but more Golden Axe than Diablo...  (Or Sacred 1/2)  and that's not a bad thing.  It DOES however feel like it started as one game, and ended up as another in some ways.  The voice acting isnt bad, but the writing seems out of place?  There are a lot of really bad jokes and some dumb one liners in there, but in a way it still comes off as charming, but seems incongruous with the presentation of the rest of the game.  That said, maybe the corn is better than having the game take itself too seriously and come off as unintentionally hokey?  Anyhow, it's a satisfying romp with lots of flying bodies and smashed set pieces, and that's pretty damn fun in of itself.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												I don't get why this game gets all the hate. I mean, sure, I only picked up the Gold Edition once it was 75% off. In fact, this is actually a review of Sacred 3 Gold at the total price of $7.50 USD. Ok? Ok.So, Sacred 3 Gold is:+ a fun, if somewhat repetitive hack'n'slash.+ Has a good variety to the levels.+ Gives you access to 6 unique warriors.+ Has a stream-lined, but flexible RPG system that allows you to easily change your specs between missions.+ Weapon Spirits add a bit of extra variety.There are things that are a bit hit-and-miss, though:= Like the humour. Absurd, low-brow, and extremely silly. You'll get a few chuckles, sure, but mostly you'll be shaking your head. (I play with the orc and he's actually pretty hilarious)= The main story levels are pre-set in their level requirements, which you will surpass very quickly. That is to say, the game will get progressively easier as you go. Don't worry, boss fights are still tough and the DLC missions adjust difficulty according to your level.= The story? Oh yeah, I forgot. ... I think you have to save the world or something?There is only, really, one issue I have with the game:- You aim your dodge with the mouse. Whoever though that was a good idea needs to have some sense knocked into them.

												I havent got a Huge amount of game time under my belt but in my hour or two (felt like ages) of playing all i can say is this.Gameplay is good, does justice (not spectacular) and is easy to get a feel for and get into which is nomally an issue with games like this. Camera panning, movement etc is fine and it works ok.Basic story... like reaaaal basic as in the kind of story you've seen on most other RPG's its not a terrible story but it feels quite droll.Now comes the fun part the voice acting and dialogue... this was something different.Imagine going to a comedy show and the act starts: "ok looks good, bit of humour (not normal in most fantasy RPG's) something different. Now imagine 5 minutes in the humour makes you cringe and if it was a live performance all you want to do is tell the comedian to sit down or just leave. Thats the dialogue and voice acting... and the sad part is it gets on you and really detracts from the rest of the game wherein you feel like you're getting the hang of a pretty ok game, something nice to pass the time with and then you get bombarded with humour that is trying so hard to be funny but simply isn't and in all honesty if the game character and story was a bit more serious (including narration, don't even get me started  great voice actor but the narration seemed offish) the game would and could have been a far more enjoyable experience.With this said the game isn't absolutely unplayable and is quite pretty in a cartoony fashion but the story and voice acting really does it in.5.7/10

												This game taught me a very valuable lesson... that is...Never, ever, ever buy a game, no matter how much you liked its predecessors, or how deeply it's dicounted... until you've read the reviews. I'll tell you how... the movement mechanic in this game is so flawed that I can't imagine a single person play testing this game and saying... "Yeah, that seems alright." It uses the standard WASD keys for movement but the view is LOCKED at a 45 degree angle to all of the corridors. So to move in a straight line down any corridor you have to either hold down 2 keys or stair step... this is SO messed up! I got Sacred 3 and all of the DLC for a great price... and I still feel ripped off, I can't imagine I'll ever boot it up again. Terrible, terrible terrible design.

It has good triple A level production value in almost every area including sound/music, graphics, controls, and gameplay, and it isn't any more or any less repetitive than any other game in it's category. However one downside that the game does have is its overly silly voice acting. It isn't like most other typical top down action rpg button mashers in that it requires you to dodge attacks with its dodge system and be at least somewhat smart while you play so you don't die. I play with a xbox 360 gamepad so I can't comment on how it plays with K&M because I never tried it but it does control perfectly with my 360 controller.It got so much hate because the fans of Sacred 1 and 2 were expecting a game like those and it is nothing at all like them. Good. Sacred 2 is old garbage. My playtime of Sacred 2 included my mage getting 3-shotted by the first couple of enemies I saw, then I went back, summoned my big demon who killed the two enemies, then turned around and killed me..... seriously? That's what they went with when they made the game? Then I made a warrior and ran around for another 45 minutes bored out of my mind. Sacred 2 lacks in every possible area that makes a game like Diablo 3 or even a f2p arpg like Path of Exile so streamlined, user friendly, and worry free. So yea I'm glad we didn't get another bad ARPG Sacred game.7.5/10 I paid $10 for this +$1.50 for the Malakhim character and it was all well worth what I paid.

content:
Posted: March 8
												Let's just get it straight out of the way...This is not like the previous Sacred games.  So if you're looking for that kind of experience then you will be very disappointed here.  Because it is such a drastically different game, I won't be judging it compared to the previous games.  That's just an unfair assessment and this game has gotten most of it's hate simply for that reason.  Since this game is a hack 'n slash action RPG, then that's what I will be comparing it to.  So games such as Champions of Norrath or Dungeon Siege 3 since those are ones I've played in the past.This game is actually pretty decent.  It accomplishes what it's trying to do, which is provide a fun hack 'n slash gameplay.  It's a simple system that anyone can easily jump into and be good at.  You're wiping out big groups of enemies, using spells or combat arts for more wide spread destruction, performing executions on knocked down enemies, evading attacks, and it all happens with just a few buttons.  There's no complicated control scheme of having to hold one button in order to open up alternative attacks or something.  It's just a fast paced, simplified system that allows you to get into the action and accomplish things in a visually pleasing way.And visually, this game is gorgeous.  The environments are extremely well done.  A lot of detail was put into this world and it's something that you can just stop and admire.  The character design is also good, but maybe a bit lacking.  I suppose it's understandable since the camera view is always pulled away and so you don't get a good look at the characters anyway.  As I mentioned, the combat is visually pleasing.  With different colors happening on the screen that are associated with your weapon swings or the different abilities.  It's a very pretty game.So if the game is nice to look at and it's a decent hack 'n slash gameplay, then you're probably wondering why a lot of people hate it.  The biggest problem this game has is there's no real depth to it.  Every good action RPG of this sort will always have the ability to progress your character.  They will allow you to level up the character and distribute attribute points, you will collect "loot" or equipment to further improve your character, you will be able to change their appearance, etc.  Sacred 3 has none of that.Character development is pretty much non-existent.  You do gain experience points and level up but it's never shown if that actually does anything.  There is no stats to say how strong your character might be or anything.  So the only purpose I've seen with leveling up is to meet the level requirements to unlock new skills.  These skills, combat arts, spells, whatever you may want to call them, are one of the very few customization that you can do.  You're only allowed to have two skills equipped and you get to choose which ones you want from a handful of them.  You can also upgrade each skill to make it more powerful.  The same thing applies with weapons you obtain.  You don't find any loot in this game but instead you get an item drop from a level boss.  These weapons can be upgraded in the same way as the skills.  There is also "weapon spirits", which for the most part are kind of useless, and they mostly will annoy you.Which brings us to the voice acting.  In general, it's not too bad.  They won't be winning any awards for their performance but I've definitely heard a lot worse.  Some characters aren't as good as others and will probably make you laugh at how bad it comes across.  But the worst part about the voice acting is they don't know when to shut up.  Whether you're being told what to do by the guide character, or you're being taunted by the enemy, or just the constant ramblings from your weapon spirit, it gets a bit annoying.  On top of that, somebody thought it was a great idea to include jokes in almost everything that is said.  Some of the humor is good but a lot of it is just kinda meh, and it gets irritating after a bit when almost everything is being said either in a joking manner or they try to slip a joke into the line of dialogue.  Such as the narrator, for example.  The purpose of a narrator is to explain what is happening to progress the story.  But this one is tossing in joke after joke and you just get tired of it and don't want to listen to him anymore.The lack of depth that I mentioned also applies to the gameplay itself.  There is so much potential that is clearly visible with this game, but, whether by choice or not, they stripped it down to the absolute basic stuff.  The environments are so detailed and there is little pathways or doorways and stuff and it makes you wish you could go explore in that direction.  But there's really no deviating from the main path.  For example, in Champions of Norrath there was caves and dungeons scattered around the map and multiple pathways you could take.  Sacred 3 has a linear path that you follow with the odd side path going into a dead end that has a chest of gold.  It's very bare bones and stripped down to just going along that path and slashing away at enemies.In conclusion, I do recommend this game but there's some conditions that go with it.  For what it is, it's a fun hack 'n slash game.  It allows you to kill swarms of enemies with a relatively decent combat system.  There's just not much to it and basically what you see in the first 5 minutes of the game is what you'll be doing for the next however many hours.  It's not a game to sit down and pull an all nighter with because you'll probably be bored after an hour or two.  So if you're looking for something simple when you need a break from everything, then this is the game to do that.As a side note...this really shouldn't have been called Sacred 3.  If they wanted to go down this style of gameplay then it should have been a spin-off game.  A lot of people hate on this game for the sole reason that it's not like the previous two.  Either way, this game has so much potential and it could have been something amazing if they added in more depth to the gameplay mechanics.

												First things first.  The game is NOT "Overwhelmingly Negative".  It's actually quite damn good.  The reason people have given it such a horrible rating is simply due to the fact that it doesn't follow in Sacred 1 & 2's roots.  Yes, that's a bummer, but the game is a damned good hack'n slash.  Including all the DLC it took me 13 hours to beat it and was level 26.  I did not do any grinding and I did not do any MP or Co-op, but might venture back in and try it out.  They should had named this something else besides Sacred 3.   Perhaps something along the lines of Sacred: Ancaria Adventures.  Then it wouldn't had gotten such a bad rep.  The graphics were beautiful and there's a continued voiced story line which was great to have.  The voices were comical and not to be taken seriously, but acceptable and enjoyable.  Lots of power ups and a few weapons to choose from.  Once you get your weapons that's all you get and then you just upgrade them.  I didn't have a problem with it.  There is NO loot system.  All you have is gold from drops or chests and use this gold to upgrade your weapons/armor and buy items (potions).  This game does take place in the Sacred world and if you're willing to play a hack'n slash beat'em up with this lore you're in for a treat.  Keen games did a fantastic job.  Great game and worth a play through!  8/10

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												By now everyone should know that this is not truly the successor to Sacred 1 and 2, despite the name. So if that is what you are looking for, move on.If you ignore the history and just evaluate the game itself, it is a solid Hack'n'Slash. It is more an advanced version of Gauntlet than a dumbed down ARPG (the point of view all the disappointed S2 fans take).If you want an ARPG, this is not the game for you, limited skill selection and no loot make this a no-go. If you want more of a brawler, go for it, combat is good enough imo, areas are nice but very linear. You collect some money per mission and can upgrade skills with it.Notice that the controls are better for a controller, so if you use keyboard and mouse and do not like WASD movement, do not get the game either (WASD works, controller is better).You also will have to overlook the stupid attempt at humor this game has in really all narration and that you unfortunately cannot turn off.If you can look past that, want a Hack'n'Slash, not an ARPG, and are ok with WASD (or better yet with using a controller), it is a solid game. Not outstanding, but also not deserving all the bad ratings from the disappointed S2 fans that are predominantly upset about this not being a true successor.

												Jsou hry, které zaslouží své místo v síni slávy a jsou hry, které bych byl raději nikdy ani nespatřil.Kde jsou ty skvělé zážitky, které jsem strávil v prvním díle Sacred? To byla skvělá doba a skvělá hra. Otevřený svět, tolik možností, skillů a zábavy. Je to pryč. Místo toho jsem měl možnost vyzkoušet třetí díl a jsem fakt zhnusen, co se může stát, když někdo dojí jméno slavné hry a zplodí brak jako tento a ještě to pokládá za plnohodnotnou hru. Toto není totiž plnohodnotná hra, ale bohapustý hnus.Dejte zbohem otevřenému světu nevídaných možností a zažijete graficky sice pěkné mapy a zajímavé efekty, ale to je tak všechno. Prvních 5 minut vás to možná i bude bavit, ale tím tahle sranda, chlapci a děvčata, jednoduše končí. Lineární, hnusně nudné, bez nápadu. Takto by se dal napsat první dojem ze hry. Vězte, že jen velmi nerad píši recenze ke hrám, které jsem neodhrál dokonce, ale mám se dost rád na to, abych podnikl toho utrpení až dokonce. Nerad bych skončil jako pacient Chocholouškova ústavu. Příběh hry je trapný a zpracování hry tomu dalo korunu. Procházíte mapu ve stylu Diablo, kosíte nepřátele, využíváte pár základních dovednotí stále dokola, občas narazíte na truhlu, ze které vám vypadnou buď peníze nebo zelené lahvičky, které jaksi doplňují život. Pokud čekáte na dropy nebo loot z nepřátel, rovnou na to zapomeňte, nepadá z nich totiž nic než prachy a zelenej chlast. Nic, prostě nic kloudného z nich nevypadne, jako z našich politiků.Hra nemá pauzu, což je tedy fakt super. Má občas jakési kruhy, které slouží jako checkpointy přes které když projdete, zamkne se vám předchozí bod mapy a můžete jen pokračovat dál. Když umřete, přijdete o 20% penež a vrátíte se na checkpoint. Jenže co když nějakou dobu hrajete a potřebujete odběhnout, třeba na záchod? No tak to vám nedoporučuji když máte nepřátele poblíž, ESC totiž zvedne menu, ale hra jede vesele dál. Asi vám nemusím říkat co následuje - vaše smrt nebo plné kalhoty. Nebo vám nejde finální boss v misi, tak si řeknete, že se k němu vrátíte například další den. Prošli jste checkpointem, takže fajn, a tak si hru zavřete. Jenže to by nebyl Sacred 3, kdyby jste po spuštení hry nebyli opět na začátku té stejné mise, co jste hráli, checkpoint je tedy naprosto k prdu. To by musel mít člověk neustále zapnutou hru. Hratelnost samotné hry je jednuduše trapná a stařičkým klasikám jako byly diablo nebo klasický Sacred 1 tento výplod choré mysli nesahá ani po kotníky. Tady to nějaké efekty a grafika za 22 GB stahování rozhodně nestojí. Postava se pohybuje jako kdyby byla předchozí den na návštěvě Modré ústřice a tak jste místy prostě děsně pomalí, což může mít často ve hře dost fatální následky. Skilly jsou nedomyšlené a ovládání kláves jde sice nastavit, ale kombinacím při pohybu a útocích jsem vůbec nepřišel na chuť, o nějaké logice ani nemluvě. Ve hře sice sbíráte prachy a zelené lahvičky na léčení, ale tyto lahvičky si jednoduše nemůžete ani sbíráním nakumulovat. V domění, že je zde něco podobného možné jsem potom celou misi chodil bez lahviček. Doměnka, že si je můžete tedy alespoň nakoupit za nasbírané peníze a mít v inventáři byla opět chybná, protože ve hře v misi nejde otevřít ani ten blbý ochod, aby to šlo koupit a lahvičky co padají prostě nenasbíráte, hra nemá inventář (!). Skilly a lahvičky jdou sice nakoupit v obchodě, ale ten není přístupný přímo ze hry v misi, nenašel jsem na to v konfiguraci ani klávesu a ESC opět nefunguje. Ten obchod jde otevřít teprve až potom, když vylezete ze hry, tedy z mise, což pokud jsem ji ještě nedokončili znamená že si ji pěkně od začátku zopakujete. Léčící lahvičky v zásobě tedy máte v určitém počtu před misí, ale během mise nelze lahvičky sbírat, ale pouze instantně použít (nedávají však až tolik života), navíc pokud je rychle neseberete, tak se ze země jednoduše vypaří, včetně peněz. Neuvěřitelné.Tato hra mi hla žlučí jako málokterá hra co jsem za poslední dobu hrál a to mě mrzí. Pokud by ji dávali někde zadarmo, řeknu vám, aby jste se podívali co může chorý mozek zplodit a zahráli si to. Ale né za 15 euro (!) a ještě 22 GB stahování tohoto braku, který nemá se Sacred nic společného a hlavně se to jednoduše nedá ani hrát bez toho, aby si člověk mezitím nemusel zajišťovat rezervaci v blázinci.Pokud se chystáte, že si tuto hru chcete pořídit a hrát, od srdce vám fandím a doufám, že to přežijete ve zdraví. Dejte však raději ruce od tohoto špatného vtipu pryč a zahrajte si třeba něco 100% napaditějšího, jako byl kdysi například stařičký Corridor 7, rozhodně dopadnete lépe :)Hodnocení: 1/10 (za odvahu toto vydat a ještě na tom rejžovat. Na to člověk musí mít fakt koule)

Posted: August 1, 2014
												This is an uncomplicated, easy to pick up, mission based isometric brawler with smooth drop-in co-op (both offline and online, up to 4 players). The main campaign can be played entirely in co-op mode, which is always a big plus. You choose between four different classes, which all feel appropriately different to play. More classes can be bought as DLC. This is not an open world game, you will be running down narrow corridors most of the time, but that kinda comes with the genre. There is no loot to speak of (only gold + health and mana orbs), instead you unlock new items and skills by leveling up or beating bosses. You can upgrade your stuff by paying gold. Bosses are varied (one can be a troll, another a ship, etc) and you need to employ different skills for each fight. XBox360 controller is recommended.All in all I must say I have enjoyed my time with this game so far, and would recommend it to anyone who is looking for something fun to play with their friends.

Posted: August 6, 2014
												This game got many negative reviews, which I find rather unfair. Sacred 3 is not Sacred or Sacred 2. It's not an RPG with an open world where you can run around and complete quests. This is what many people expected and why so many are disappointed. Sacred 3 is an extremely linear Hack'n Slash game with lots of action and (in my opinion) nice graphics. It takes place in Ancaria. That's pretty much all it has in common with its predecessors.Nevertheless, it is a decent game. The visuals are well done, controls are intuitive (if you play with a controller) and accurate. You constantly need various buttons which are much easier to reach on a controller than a keyboard. Further, the game has a online as well as a local co-op mode. Playing with others is much more fun and something I would definitely recommend to do.The only thing I found annoying after a while are the comments of your companions. I guess, the developers aimed at being funny. They are not. I prefer a more serious tone in the dialogues while I'm saving the world. It's not the right time to hear about wannabe romantic approaches of whatever kind of ghost I'm carrying around with me.TL, DR: This is a good game with some minor flaws. It missed the high expectations from its loyal fans and got many undeserved bad reviews for it.

												First of all: this game in terms of gameplay, it has absolutely nothing to do with the first two Sacred. NOTHING.This important premise goes done, because it can help you a lot to not judge the game negatively from the begin, without any reason particularly founded.I wanted to give it a chance, after having read the users assaults in the forums, a hatred which, however, was almost always motivated only by the fact that "this isn't Sacred".Said that, I like the game. From begin I have found friends to play co-op, and also in single objectives to achieve allow you to play for many hours.In co-op is great fun, the locations of the missions are very varied and graphically detailed, a nice isometric game that sometimes offers beautiful panoramic views.The interactivity with the map is quite varied, you can break any small object, even if it has no utility except for the energy or health orbs.Each weapon has its own power and skill tree to upgrade, although the RPG elements are few.The replay value is very good, after the "normal" level there are two levels of high difficulty, and the map of the world starts from the beginning, even if you can go in all the main missions.Sacred 3 can give you many hours of carefree fun.The online system works well, and play in co-op (especially 4) is really fun, and it is this that matters.If you can disinterest that has nothing to do with the previous chapters, and you can catalog it in a completely different genre, then you can definitely like Sacred 3.However, if you expect a game similar to Sacred 1 or 2, I do not recommend it, because you will be disappointed.7.3/10

First of all:Yes this is not Sacred.It isnt open world,it hasnt any characteristics of any popular hack`n slay (besides the iso view maybe) and its by far not a perfect game.Everyone who was interested in Sacred 3 before its release should have known that since it was announced the way it is(without loot,no open world,easy actioner) and blaming devs for not changing their mind on the idea they announced to you months ago is a bit stupid if you bought the game nontheless.Anyway if you are able to lower your expectations to a point where you will not judge the game by the fact that it isnt sacred and/or the new Diablo then the game at least brings a bit of fun with it.The Review Discussion:You might have seen the game got a lot of neg. Reviews and Hate.This mainly contains due the fact that most people judged the game without giving it a real chance at all.Most people simply started the game,saw its not like sacred 1 + 2 and instantly downvoted the game.Most of this reviews have playtimes less then an hour and remind me more of some "true believers"driven by their own madness then actual intelligent people.The Game has a lot problems and is by far not a AAA Game but its not THAT terrible as many people wanna make others think.The GameThe Game itself is fairly easy to explain : Its a very simply Isometric Action Game with very little till no real RPG Elements with its focus on fast-paced Multiplayer Action.Basically you run around with a variety of very little combat skills/attacks and try to kill as much as possible as fast as possible.You gain xp and level up`s and you can collect gold(which is your only "Loot") with what you are able to buy new skills/abilities for yourself,your weapons or armor.The Game is devided into 4 Difficulties in total and has a max level of 50.The Storymode is not open world,its divided into Missions,which come along with a Recommendation of the level you should have for the particular mission of your choice.Anyway you can jump into every Mission at any point(Eg. playing a lvl 25 mission with the player level of 5 and so on)The DownsidesFirst the game is massively overprized on Steam.So like everyone smart should do with any other game aswell : Go check the Keyshops of your trust or wait for a sale...The Game itself is pretty buggy : From Resolution bugs till Random Crashes it involves everything.Graphics are okish but really look outdated,especially textures,backgrounds in general and the very lowres Overlays.The Soundtrack tho is great.Really nice composed and fitting and definitely one of the best parts of the game.The Voice acting on the other hand not so much... Partly good,partly wierd,partly really bad.The Game itself and the way it plays out is somewhat fun.I mean it doesnt have any depth or real challenge but for a one-time run especially in multiplayer its fun to play.Where it disappoints the most is the lack of inspiration imo.I dont care if its like Sacred 1+2 and I was 100% sure it wouldnt be on any level close to D3 or PoE and i can totally live with it being a better melee combat game but its really sad how less inspiration devs gave into the combat system.I mean when i focus a game on fast-paced action then ffs i have to take care that the combat system is more then just 4 button mash.Involve some Combo possibilites,more skills whatever to keep people challenged or motivated also in single player.With 4 people it doesnt matter that the fight and skill system doesnt have any substance since its about having some fun but in single player it really bothers me,that its that one-sided and plain boring after a bit.Thats btw the biggest problem S3 has overall : Long-Term Motivation.Yes you have a max cap of 50 but srsly after you beat the game once (pretty much with level 25 around) the problems with the missions are kicking in.Basically you can just replay the whole game exactly the same way as you did before just with a higher difficulty.Challenging/Motivating : Not so much since voiceacting,level design,waves whatever is exactly the same as you played before so that it feels like the additional 25 more XP level where added later to make the game look as it would have a longer playtime.The EndAll in All its not a terrible game.Its a short,fun,multiplayer-focused action-slasher for a few hours.Nothing more,Nothing less.If you want a Sacred 1/2 Reloaded or a new Dia 3 this is not a game for you and you will end up disappointed but if you can take it as it is it at least gives you some hours of fun.Anyway I´d recommend waiting for a sale or use other sources since 50 bucks for this seems a bit overprized at this point.5.5/10

												First things first.  Banish the idea of "Sacred" from your mind.  Erase it.  Done? Good.  This isn't Sacred.  The closest existing Sacred game is Sacred Citadel.  But that doesn't make this game bad.  Remember those good old days you spent during your youth? Pumping quarters into a game called Guantlet?  Yeah, this is that, except conveniently located on your home PC/Console, where you can love it forever.Despite others calling it a "mindless button-masher", there is a bit of thought involved when combating a massive wad of enemies.  You have standard attack, "Bash" (shield breaker), dodge/block, throw/power attack (used on boss type critters to deal a decent chunk of damage), a Light and Heavy Combat Art that use energy, and an Execution to 1-hit knocked down enemies.  Trust me, nothing feels quite like knocking down a group of enemies and then hopping from one to the next with murderous force.Main levels generally consist of moving from arena to arena, mashing through waves of enemies until the barrier disapates, or you get a key drop from some sub-boss, or you clear X number of waves.  But since you enjoyed Gauntlet back in the day, that's not a problem, right?  The only "loot" is gold, which you use to upgrade your character between levels, unlocking boosts to combat arts, weapons, and other things, as well as buying potions and the like.Is this Sacred 2++ (thats "2 incremented by 1" for you non programming oriented people)? No.Is it fun? Sure, why not?Ignore the fact that it has Sacred in the title, embrace the fact that it is an "arcade hack and slash" (as it says in the description, for those of you complaining about it being exactly that), round up some friends, and bludgeon some goblins or whatever they are to a bloody pulp for fun and profit.PS: You really want a controller if you're on PC, cause it may or may not destroy your keyboard.  And it was designed for controllers, so the keyboard controls are probably awkward.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												It is certainly a departure from the more RPG-like approach of Sacred 1 and 2, which felt more involving, more in-depth and a lot more customisable. That doesn't mean Sacred 3 is bad, it is just -- very different.The game seems to be geared for 15-20 minute short sessions of gameplay, either on your own or with friends / strangers, focussing on quick gameplay and hi-scores, with over-the-top effects and repetitive sections of enemy waves to re-iterate the notion of "Kill all the monsters, make sure you get the highest score!" While the story is very cheesy and is rather boring after a while, the sound effects and music work well, and some of the enemies are quite nicely designed. Again, nothing amazing, but good enough for a bit of fun.I've certainly enjoyed playing the game with other players so far, and I must say I enjoyed it. Don't think of it as Sacred 3. Think of it as a co-op-geared action game in the Sacred universe. Is it value for money? That really depends on who you play with, if you're playing on your own then definitely not. If you play as a group and take on all of the optional challenges to see who comes out on top, then do give it a go

												It's a decent game when you get passed that it does not fall in line with the other "sacred" games.  The game itself is not too hard, being there is diff levels, play at your own toughness.  I really wanted this game to be a good timewaster but I feel that it's going to be one of those beat it and be done with it kind of games.The loot is pretty much non-existat there are a few things here and there you get, however, I don't think they in much RNG involved more of where you are at the level or the story/The skills and abilites are nice, but the lack of attacks make me wonder why, one of the warrior attacks does not even do damage is more of a debuff or stun/interupt which is fine but when you only have 4 I feel it's a waste of a free action move.Graphics are ok.  Playing this at 2560X1440 helps it look good, with some odd very odd coding, as my 780ti will ramp up and get as hot at 79c while most of the time it sits at 66-67, seems as if parts of the game were not optimized fully.  No sli support out of the gate, (should not need it though)Biggest Con for me though is the very bad voice over scripts not so much the voices but what they say.  Very corny,The telepathic helper if you call her that can be very annoying, when you have 500 mobs on you and she deemands you spin the wheel, I mean wtf can't you sense that I am trying to but have to deal with the mobs first. I understand why they did it, to move the story along for perhaps the "unaware" Oh and don't get me started on the spirits, the ones the fuse to your weapon, most of the time they bad stats out weigh the good ones or they become a wash to what's the point in them.  All they do is provide more "Corny" dialogue that is not needed, I mean you already have one annoying person talking to you, do we really need another?   Not to mention the enemies scripts.  It's just really really bad.  However, if you can get passed all that, and I mean it might take a strong willed person, there is a good game under it all, as it stands it is a beat em up, with a small RPG element to it, and I say small because its more of a straight line RPG, sure you can go back and gain some levels, but then all you are doing is out leveling the content to make it easy, why not just change the diff then.I don't feel rewarded enough in the game, but I will finish it and most likley edit this review, as it stands it's a good game, with many holes.Worth the 49.99? NoIf you can get it cheaper the better imo. I feel this game should of been released at 29.99 being what it is right now.  Finishing the game and seeing what is beyond might change my tune, but I paid full price and knew going into it I was not going to get my moneys worth at least right away.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												If your intent with this game is a big, open, exciting world full of lore and loot, you will be sadly dissappointed. Though, discounting this game simply because of experiences with with the prior titles would cause you to miss out on a world of fun. While it lacks the deep story and customization of Sacred and Sacred 2, the new combat system is a blast to use. The story, so far anyway, is lackluster and disinteresting, but that's not what this game is about.For those of you who have gotten this far, you'll like this game if you're a fan of games like Dynasty Warriors as, ironically, that's what this game feels like. In my opinion, if Sacred made a baby with the Warriors games, this is what I'd expect it to look like. Given that, I'm not surprised by the lack of story or deep customization because the intense combat is the focus. In the future, I personally hope that this combat system is kept and the old system of loot and quests brought back. I really believe that this is a step forward for the combat of the ARP genre.If you can just look past the Sacred title and the history of the series, I think most will enjoy this game. Worst comes to worst, wait for a sale, but I do not suggest those interested in the ARP genre should pass it up.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												The first two Sacred games were ARPG Diablo clones; in a countless list of those going towards the early 2000's Sacred was one of the best alternatives for those that already destroyed Diablo. Sacred 2 more recently took a page from other ARPGs, but remained a stat-based action roleplaying game, just like Diablo.Sacred Citidel would have been right at home on Kongregate or at an Arcade - it was a mediocre Castle-Crashers style beat'em'up side-scrolling RPG. SACRED 3 hads a lot of people frothing at the mouth about how it was not true to its own roots, and it's being accused universally of being a bad game, it is not!People are reviewing what they expected, rather than what the game is. Sacred 3 is a mixture of Sacred 1/2 and Sacred Citadel, that does not try to be an alternative to Diablo 3 (Torchlight 2 is better). In fact, what it is, is a Really Decent classic hack'n'slash adventure game. There isn't much of a loot system, there are no real stats, you sort of have levels, it's not really an RPG. It is better at being what I expected from the Gauntlet reboot (Coming later in August 2014) than what Gauntlet 2014 looks to be.Fans of Diablo? Stay away. Missing the smashfest days of Dark Legacy? Come get some. Bring a friend and a controller.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												I've played the game for about 10 hours.  and I have to say that for what the game is... it's an enjoyable distraction for awhile.  there is definitly a lot of variation in the levels that you will come across in the game.  Also I would say that the character's abilities are different enough that you would want to try each of them to see what best fits your play style.  As for the name of the game Sacred 3, many people are getting stuck on this.  Yes I've played and have beaten both Sacred 1 and 2.  aid if you are expecting to find a game like that,  then unfortunatly you will be sadly disappointed.  and like many have said, perhaps giving this game another name would have most likely been a better option.  About the only thing that this game holds true to the sacred name is some of the characters and of course the setting of the game itself.  Pros for the game:- Good graphics- Drop in/drop out multiplayer.  - the player level advancement is well paced as you move through the levels- varied boss and monster mechanics- Unique enough playable characters that you would want to try all of themCons for the game:- It's sacred in name and name only this is for the most part a top down hack 'n slash- Character development is extremely limited you can only unlock/upgrade skills by reaching certain levels- Finding upgrades is linked to specific levels in the game- Game really isn't mouse/keyboard friendly, was definitly designed with consoles in mindOver all.  the game is a nice nice distraction for awhile and also a good addition to the Sacred Universe of games but has been preveriously stated, this game really doesn't desver the title of Sacred 3 and in face this type of game could possibly spawn it's own series within the sacred universe and would have honestly been a better idea.
