content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Russian and EnglishИтак - к делу. Очень неплохой hack-and-slash в стиле Диабло, но с сильным уклоном в сторону аркады. Аркадность игры компенсируется РПГ-элементами, однако без системы Диабло - то-есть теперь снаряжение открывается за уровни опыта, а берется за золото. Процесс уничтожения врагов не заставляет "сильно напрягатся" с одной стороны, а с другой - хотите серъёзней - ставьте уровень сложности повыше. Экипировка и умения дают возможность подобрать собственный стиль - здесь игра идеальна для всех игроков. Игра в ко-опе помогает немного быстрее набирать опыт и золото - здравствуй Диабло. В целом что сказать - здравствуй Sacred 3 после бездарного Sacred 2 - хорошо во всём - но... Во-первых почему нет звука в стартовой заставке? Во-вторых не совсем удачно подобраны реплики "духов оружия" - обещали нам что те расскажут историю Анкары, а на деле они просто фоновая озвучка игрового процесса. В третьих - графика: неплоха, но что-то маловато по сравнению с первым Sacred. В четвертых - камера иногда совершает повороты в связи со интро-сценами и в тот момент не очень удобно бежать, благо там нет врагов. И последнее - слишком много не нужной секс-тематики в репликах, слишком простенькая экипировка со старта и, самое плохое, консольность - хотя управление на ПК нормальное.В целом - берите, но из ДЛС советую только доп. миссии - остальное позже.So - lets start. Very good hack-and-slash Diablo style but with big shift to arcade. Arcade elements are compensaded with RPG-elements allow game to avoid catch-the-loot Diablo style - gear is opening for exp and equipping for gold. Process of cleaning mobs aren't difficult - but if you want challenge, just switch to higher difficulty - gear and skills allow any player mix their own combo - on that this game is ideal for any player. Co-op game allow to boost exp and gols - hello Diablo. In general what can i say - hello Sacred 3, after poor Sacred 2 - good in all, but...First - where is sound at the intro. Second - not quite good voice acting of spirits - devs promised that they will tell us story of Ancara, but they more "talk in action" when we killing mobs. Third - graphics - not bad, but that is all - compare with Sacred 1 it's moderate. Fourth - camera make some rotate in game intro-scenes, run at that moment isn't very comfortable but good that there are no enemies. And the last - too many intimacy at the voice-acting, too simple gear from beggining and the last and most worse - console-style - however on PC cointrols are normal.In general - game is worth, but in DLC advise you to take only story expansion - rest later.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												Much like Dungeon Siege 3, Sacred 3 has little in common with its predecessors besides a name, setting and bright, colourful visuals. It's not so much an 'action RPG' as it is an 'arcade RPG' - more Gauntlet than Diablo. Pick one of four (five via preorder or DLC) pre-made hero/ines and get down to the business of clicking stuff until it dies.In many ways, Sacred 3 has more in common with the download-only Sacred Citadel than its heavier RPG brothers - it's a button mashing brawler at heart, with linear levels and only as much level-up and customisation option as necessary to give the player some agency. Collectibles are limited to helth, energy and gold - the latter being used to buy upgrades or new skills when you level up.There's no denying Sacred 3 won't be everyone's cup of tea - it is practically designed for couch co-op with friends and beers, or breezy online play while you and your mates mash buttons and talk trash. It has that quirky European sense of humour that made Sacred 2 surprisingly funny, although tempered by what the developers clearly think an American audience will find funny (and spoiler alert, you probably won't). That said, it has an awkward charm about it that'll either make you snicker, or at least roll your eyes with a smile.Performance wise, the game runs flawlessly on my machine, the first $50+ game in quite a few months to do so (Wolfenstein, Watch Dogs I am looking at you). The visuals aren't amazing and shouldn't tax most systems, but the art style is big and colourful and mostly pleasing on the eye. Playing on my 46" TV it can be a bit hard to make out what is going on when there's a lot of enemies on the screen, but it's usually only a few seconds until everything is dead from one of your combat abilities.The music is good and the voice acting is serviceable, although leaning towards the annoying end of the spectrum. There's a surprising amount of it too, with various 'souls' you can equip for a passive bonus, and each one has its own personality and one-liners. Word to the wise: the default guy you get is super annoying, so don't forget you can switch him out after a mission or two.All in all, Sacred 3 is a competent hack & slash adventure, one best experienced with friends and in shorter sessions. It's far from perfect, and it's a departure from its predecessors, but with Divinity: Original Sin out there to get your more traditional RPG fix, this is the perfect antidote for when you just want to switch off your brain and bash some orcs.

												The game holds the name Sacred 3 upon itself, but it's a very different game from its predecessors. There is no open world here, there isn't real loot you'll find dropping from your enemies, just gold, health globes and energy globes.The story seems silly and from the start it's apparent that the game doesn't take itself seriously at all, beginning from the narrator, continuing to what the NPCs say including even your own character and the Souls attached to your weapons.You play in confined levels that can be pretty short or somewhat long that you pick from a map, after which you get dropped into the level and that you'll navigate until the boss fight at the end, after which you'll leave.After certain fights (usually Bosses that I've seen) you'll find new Souls for your weapon, as well as new weapons that you'll be able to use (and upgrade if you are high level enough and have enough gold) after completing the mission.The action is pretty hectic, with enemies attacking in droves while the player has to try and dodge out of the way of powerful attacks, break the shield of bigger enemies to be able to hurt them or stop certain enemies from casting (or interrupt althogether their spell) all the while managing the use of skills that use a limited energy resource.Personally, I wanted this to be closer to the old games, something more akin to Sacred 2 but, so far, I have been having fun with what this game has to offer. The action can get very busy and even at the normal level of difficulty I found that dying can become rather easy if not paying attention at getting out of the way. Killing the groups of enemies coming at you and emerging victorious is also another fun aspect of the game.The commands are responsive, the game looks quite nice and performs really well even when downsampling from something like 2880x1620.I have found a problem with the game crashing whenever I open the friend menu in game but I'm not sure if that's the game or something on my PC.All in all, the experience with the game so far is really positive. Probably not an experience worth 50€, but I didn't pay that much for it when I preordered, so it's more of a problem for anyone that would want to grab the game now.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Sacred 3 promises a third person isometric hack n slash arcade RPG, and it definitely delivers. Sacred 3 brings all of the wit and humour of Sacred Citadel to a faster, more arcade feeling gaming experience with engaging story, interesting characters and completely functional, highly competitive 4 player co-op. Though, the price point may be a little high for the content.	The loot is all but gone from this game, staying true to the arcade feel. Instead you are awarded weapons and weapon upgrades, items, item slots and armor upgrades by completing story and side missions. The weapon and armor upgrades are given to you in a cycle through completing story missions; Weapon 1, Weapon 2, Weapon 3, Armour. Start again with the next four story missions. You progress through these missions through a hub-based world map guided by the Seraphim Aria, and each node on the map can take between 2 and 20 minutes to complete. These range from clearing out a single pathway, surviving 5 waves of enemies to sieging a fortress.  You can visit any node on the map at any time, in any order and however many times you wish, though the final encounter only unlocks after all other story missions have been cleared. A single clear through the map will take you roughly 8 playing hours, 10 for the second. The replayability comes from multiple characters, chasing high scores and playing with your friends.	As you traverse each map node, of which there are 40, the telepathic Seraphim Aria will attempt to guide you. She is only a novice, so don't be too hard on her! She will give you helpful pointers for where to go and roughly what to do, though it is worth mentioning that if you ignore her suggestions, she will harass you until you do it which can become a little bit annoying at times.	The game's difficulty settings ARE actually what they say they are. Knight (Easy) is mindnumbingly easy for a skilled player. You should be in absolutely no danger on this mode, even if you've never played a video game of any kind before. Champion (Medium) is a little more difficult, but nothing short of bosses should give you any trouble. Legend (Hard) is the first difficulty in which health potions should even be needed. You definitely don't want to look away from a fight here! Once you have completed the map on Knight, Champion or Legend, Deity (Impossible) becomes available. Deity increases the suggested level and difficulty of each node on the map, and will be very difficult if attempted without at least one other party member, and it is here that the co-op multiplayer really shines. 	The co-op multiplayer is entirely optional, however. Drop in/drop out co-op can be disabled by setting your play session to 'private' if you're more the single player type. You will not be forced to play with any AI companions for doing this either. If you'd rather not have the Online feature at all, Sacred 3 does have an offline mode. Should you choose to partake in the co-op multiplayer, you will be in the same playspace as between 1 and 3 other players. You will work together to clear the map in a strange but kind of fun blend of cooperation and oneupmanship. Exactly how points are awarded is unclear at this point. Simply killing more enemies than your cooperators is not enough to come out with the high score. HOW you kill them matters too. If one of your party members falls in battle, reviving them will also score you some points. 	The combat is fast and functional, with new combat arts for each of the four new classes and the returning Seraphim to use, as well as weapon spirits and three weapons each. Each weapon has it's own unique specialty to suit your playstyle. Do you like to keep enemies on their back? Plough through them with brutal force? Dance around the battlefield? It's up to you! Though it is worth nothing that some features/actions are shared between the five classes, so to a certain degree once you have played one it will be very easy to get into another one, and after a while the cycle of dodge and attack starts to feel samey.	Weapon spirits are shards that you collect at random throughout Ancaria, each with it's own personality and modifier for your abilities, ranging from lifesteal, party buffs, shielding, damage reduction, enemy debuffing and more. The spirits have voices, and speak to you as well as your party. This companionship between weapon and wielder adds quite a bit of fun to the game, as the running commentary brings out a lot of laughs. You level them up by finding more shards, boosting their power and thusly, the effect they pass on to you.	Every aspect of your character (with the exception of weapon spirits) are upgradeable using gold found throughout the game. Once you have reached the level requirement to be elligible for the upgrade, you can buy it with gold to boost or change the function of your weapons, armor, combat arts, as well as to buy consumables. There is plenty of gold to be found in the game, so you will usually have more gold than upgrades to spend it on, taking the grind out of the equation.The enemies vary in strength and skills as the game progresses, though they seem to share some abilities from level 1 and on, only adding either extra abilities or extra effects to make them more dangerous, though there is very little variety in the enemies themselves. Most of the bosses feel bossy, but these can be usually be navigated simply by dodging away when they attack and not standing in the goo. Only a handful of the bosses have any mechanics that make fighting them different from any other. The game does start to feel samey in this regard.		The game has full mouse, keyboard and gamepad support as well as built-in voice communication service. However it is readily apparent that this is a console port as it feels way more natural to play the game with a gamepad. The default keyboard and mouse settings feel somewhat obtuse. Though you are able to map the keyboard and mouse as well as the gamepad to your preference, so with some tweaking the game is very playable with either.	The visuals, special effects, voice acting and optimisation are phenominal. The game is pure beauty, with amazing environments, smooth camera angles and lively and vibrant voice acting. 	All told Sacred 3 and it's prequel, Sacred Citadel are GREAT games, and I recommend that any isometric RPG or arcade brawler fan play them. However it is my personal hope that Sacred 4, should there be one, return to the loot-crazed, open worlded and more serious toned Sacred and Sacred 2: Fallen Angel crafted by Ascaron. There are only two jokers in a deck. Deep Silver has played both.Notable bugs/issues(PC):-The game is 20GB for no apparent reason.-The game does not remember your resolution setting from one session to the next-The game locks up without warning and without reason from time to time-Crash to desktop-Sometimes can't equip certain weapons for no apparent reason-Steam overlay sometimes sticks to the edges of the screen in-game.

YouTube™ Video: Sacred 3 review - no nonsense Hack 'n' Slashing 

			Views: 14,147		

			A review of Sacred 3 from Deep Silver which is available on Xbox 360/PS3 and PC. Enjoy the video please subscribe to help grow the channel.		

In a nutshell, Sacred 3 is a solid hack and slash game that offers a no nonsense approach that's easy to pick up and play for those who want to hammer away at few attack buttons and little else for several hours. There's no menus to wade through or complexity of character progression which means players who thirst for killing can do so without hindrance.  In this regard the game succeeds, but at the same time does become repetitive quite quickly unless you're well in tune with levelling up your character, or willing to try the others classes to add some variety. As mentioned, if you're a fan of the previous games that afford more depth and exploration, then you're going to probably feel a little let down with what's on offer here as the game is Sacred by name, but certainly not in execution.Score 7/10 - Review By  Robert Cram

												Nothing like the previous titles, but pretty good nonetheless.First of all, I'd suggest avoiding the game completely if you don't have a controller. The keyboard and mouse set up is awful.Secondly, it isn't open world, so if that's your thing, the game will disappoint.As for the game itself. It's exactly as advertised. An arcade hack 'n' slash. We all wanted Sacred 3 to be an open world/dungeon crawler/adventure rpg and possibly some more Blind Guardian. ;)Having bought the game £10 cheaper than for sale on Steam and having all the DLC thrown in, I can't complain.I'd much rather have an open world Sacred, but so far I have been enjoying the game.Definitely not worth the £40 Steam are looking for. And if open world is your thing, avoid at all costs.Seems like it'll be a great little time killer, though. If in doubt wait for a sale. :P

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Sacred 3 is a bit of a mixed bag, and innovates the series in an opposite direction, but is a decent time waster when on 75% off.I had never played a Sacred game before this. So when I saw this game I was impressed by it's art style and the dungeons in it's screenshots. However the game was immediately swarmed by negative reviews and as it stands it is one of the worst games on Steam.But does it deserve that distinction.As someone who only now (as of this review) just played Sacred 2, I have to say I had better first impressions of Sacred 3, but that's not to say that the criticism is unfounded.First of all, the game is level based, instead of open world. The story is about generic evil bad guy overlord called Zane tries to take over Ancaria. And the Seraphim form a team of warriors to fight him off. Pretty boring stuff. The levels while linear as hell are at least nice to look at, and the visual effects as enemies are slaughtered are satisfying. However, the combat is poor. Clicking the left mouse button attacks, right mouse button counters (in a way, it just stuns most opponents when they are about to strike.) Pressing 1 or 2 activates a special ability. Yes, you can only have 2 abilities instead of a full bar. And as abilities go they are pretty generic. You can also dodge roll, but it sucks. Because you roll in the direction of your MOUSE, and not in the direction of your WASD or whatever you use. At least with keyboard and mouse controls. It might be better with a controller.Customization of characters and equipment, ready for it? Is ♥♥♥♥ing NONEXISTANT. Weapons are gained at certain points in the story, and upgrades are basic up damage, up crit, up range etc. You cannot get new armour or anything, and levelling up just gets you more upgrades. It might actually be better if levelling wasn't in the game at all to be honest, but they had to make this as RPG-y as possible I guess.The story and dialougue is the most unfunniest bull you will ever hear and read in your life. And this is someone who loves games like Stick RPG 2 and Duke Nukem Forever (DNF's writing anyway, the gameplay can go to hell). I find the writing in Sacred 3 some of the dumbest♥♥♥♥♥♥I've ever had to hear, and it looks like a game script I would write at the age of NINE. Freaks sakes. But I actually enjoy the writing, because we all need some lame humour in our lives every now and then, and Trump jokes are overdone.And the dlcs are kinda... mediocre. You get basically more missions of the same friggin gameplay, which is actually my biggest complaint about Sacred 3. It is repetitive as hell. Even the side missions are killmobs.gif. Because it repeats. Over. And. Over.The game, in my opinion, can be best described as an unfunnier Borderlands, with no loot worth playing for, and cringier dialogue. So why do I recommend it then?Like I said at the start, I find it a mixed bag. I have stated all negatives so far, but there is one thing that I recommend it for.When you are bored as hell, or stressed, and just want to play something stupid. Something you don't want to pay much attention too. Just an arena for you to beat up orc and trolls. That's what it's for. It also helps if you are drunk, but hey.Do get this on a sale though, you don't want to pay full price for something that is basically fun for 5 minutes at a time.
